												I'll be completely up front, I have not played one minute of this game (my time in game represents background idling for cards while I did other things). So if it's an in depth discussion of how Two Worlds II plays is what you are after, move on and read another review.What this game does have, and why I won't be playing it is DRM that takes intrusiveness to new heights. In order to complete the registration process, it wants me to supply my street address, date of birth, and gender? I see no reason to supply this information to a game developer in order to play a game. I have no interest in entrusting my time to a game by a developer that has such little respect for my privacy. I decided to opt out by uninstalling the game and never playing it. I leave this review for others who may want to opt out by never getting it in the first place.

												this game is actually way too good for the rpg genre. it has great magic, fighthing and character development systems. it has horse riding and sailing, platform jumping, sneaking, thieving, assassinations, huge dungeons, caves, many monsters and items for loot etc etc...but unfortunately it is an incomplete game. most prolly it's developer ran out of money in the project and had to release it prematurely. more than half of the maps are deserted! no loot, no monsters, no missions, nothing. you run around hoping to see some things but mostly it's just empty terrain...for example <spoiler> third chapter takes place in the middle of an island inbetween some high rock walls and believe it or not, you can't get out of the rock walls and roam the rest of the island </spoiler>. very silly indeednevertheless it is a very good and stable game with more than 50hrs of game play for average rpg fan...would i recommend it? no, not in it's premature state...but do get it if you find it under some steam sales. it's definitly worth it...

content:
8, 2015
												Normally my opinion is very standard and mainstream so 99% of the time I agree when a game has many negative reviews. This time I cannot agree because the first hours I started this game I had so much fun. It reminds me of Ultima and Morrowind. The world is really open and huge and even if you follow the main story you have plenty of possibilties to explore on your own. Direct from the beginning you can have a huge profit if you start reading the books and looting the chests you find and the artwork is really stunning even for todays standards. The opening cinematic is really nice and made you feel really part of the world.The crafting system is fun because useless items give you resources and this resources you can use to upgrade your valueable items.Like in Morrowind you can develop your character while you play and you are not restricted to only one class.If you read the turorial messages it give you all information about key bindings and while it's sometimes annoying at the beginning to make your character do what you want him/her to do, but like in real life after some practice you become comfortable with it.There is a lot of character interaction, but it never gets annoying because you don't  have to read pages of gossip. If you want more information about subjects you can read the books or buy the strategy guides on Steam.I bought the game long time ago before it was on sales on Steam and don't regret. I bought the strategy guides now just to tell the devs I really like this game.Most important of all is that I really think the devs have passion for their project and that's what you can see in every single part of the game. I don't understand people rating this so negative without explaining what is so wrong about the game just because they were asked for their profile when starting the game. Get over it.If you like exploring every part of the world in your own story with your own character doing what you like to do and want a huge adventure with fighting monsters and explore secrets don't think twice to get this chem now when it's on sale.

content:
16, 2014
												I'm happy to say that this game is a HUGE improvement over the first Two Worlds game. First, let me say the bad news:The combat is still kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but not so horrible that you can't enjoy the game. Sometimes, the combat is an absolute joy because it is a tad wonkly and I had many laughs because of it.Horses still suck AND there's no horse combat. Not even one step forward, huh? 2 steps back and that's it. Meh.Visuals are fine, but some character models are just gross.Voice overs still suck, but who cares. UI kinda sucks, but it's usable. Hell, I think MechWarrior's UI 2.0 is just fine, so take my opinion for what it's worth.Still a ton of bugs, just like Two Worlds I.Now the good. HUGE improvements on everything, even on the things that still kinda suck. Within the context of this series, that's a good thing. At least they learned.OH MY GOD the magic! The combos for magic, warrior abilities, and archer/thief stuff is great. SO MANY POSSIBILITIES. I dig that, I really do.Big map, lots of baddies to kill. I like. The teleportation system is 10x better and more reminiscent of something out of TES. That's a good design, keep it, it works.And the quest system is great and the story is...eh, not so horrible. It's not great, but it'll do.Character customization is waaaay better, and that's good. However you still can't make a female in single player mode, DAFUQ, TopWare? All in all, I give it a 6.5/10 would probably bang again.

content:
er 27, 2013
												Two Worlds II is your typical fantasy adventure/RPG game with loads of enemies, challenges, things to do, average story-telling & plot, mediocre graphics and a very grindy multiplayer. However.. Even though this game has got some flaws it does deliver on some areas which makes it all worth the while.As far as the single-player story goes it's nothing special, really. It's very generic and the character you play as is very easy to forget about (lacking background-story, no real connection). None of the main characters really stand out. Instead, those who you talk to once in a while are those with the most memorable dialog and unique sense of humour - which is a neat change of pace.When you venture out in the singleplayer world it's easy to let go of what you were doing and just hunt for enemies only to use your skills, no matter what you specialize in at the time whether it be magic, archery, melee combat or all three. They are all equally as fun to play, even though the magic-system in this game is by far the most worked on.You conjure your own spells by using cards which you can combine in almost any way you can think of. You can create spells which summon creatures to fight for you, spells which summon tornados which in turn summons heavy steel anvils - at the same time as it's spinning around throwing the anvils all around the place. Or if you're more into projectiles you can create spells which shoot out several projectiles that are either homing or simply bounces through target to target hitting multiple enemies with only one projectile. OR; combine it all - projectile -> anvile summoning -> Tornado. Great fun!However, this game is not only about singleplayer, even though it's great fun. You can also join your friends on Multiplayer where the game turns into somewhat of a grind-fest and all you do - basically - is repeat mission in order to gain levels and increase the strength of your character. Yes, it's tedious.. But with the right people the multiplayer turns into a very much appreciated hang-out. You have several game-modes ranging from the typical story-mission style to sruvival and even town-management. Yes, you can build your bery own town/village and you have to manage it in order to keep your villagers happy. And you friends can join you in your village, to either help you out when you need to defend it or to see how you manage your village compared to theirs.There's also PvP in this game, but my experience with the PvP has been very bad which in the long run made me ignore it completely, so I'm not gonna comment on it.All in all it's a great game. The graphics are very dated since the game is old, but even though it looks "bad" it still delivers on key points; massive world(s), great environment, huge variety of enemies, great skill-set and system, basic crafting and upgrading system and more. It's a great game when you want to kill time or play something quick and easy with your friends.I've enjoyed every minute put into this game, and I believe some of you will as well. Not everyone - but some!

number of helpful: 85 of 103 people (83%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
12, 2014
												When you first start playing, the jerky camera work and non-intuitive movement/combat system might make you want to stop playing...you should follow that instinct. After you get through the interface's learning curve, you stumble on to an actually decent action-RPG. Think Gothic but without interesting characters or a world that makes you care about. While I realize that's not a glowing recommendation, most of the game is actually enjoyable. The side-quests are interesting, and there are some genuinely funny moments. Unfortunately, you're never really *in* the game, because conversations are abysmal. The voice-acting is very poor, as are the conversation animations. You have to constantly refer to your journal for synopses, because the in-game dialogue is sometimes borderline nonsensical and leaves one wondering what actually just happened. All that aside, it's perfectly possible to get tens of hours of solid gameplay out of this title...until you come to the final boss. I won't offer spoilers, but I will say that the mechanics of the final boss fight essentially toss aside all of the character building you've worked towards. The RPG elements die, only to be replaced by a clunky FPS/potion management test. Due to the game's refusal to let you save during the final battle, you will also be subjected to the final cutscreen each re-try (and there will be many, many re-tries if you actually want to win). In other words, it starts out clunky, gets decent without ever being really good, and then ends with the least enjoyable boss fight I've ever encountered in a game. I suppose the good news is that the characters are so unrelateable and uninteresting that I never felt compelled to power-through and beat the final boss, so on the positive side, at least you don't feel like you've lost too much if you never find out how the story ends. If you have to play the game, just stop at the final boss and look online for a final cutscreen.

content:
9, 2014
												Well I was pleasantly surprised. There is a lot going for this game and it really is an improvement on the first game in the series. I thought the main character was a hoot. I loved the very dry but funny comments he made throughout the game. I liked the side quests, they were interesting and entertaining and usually quite unpredictable in how they would turn out. I enjoyed the storyline, I certainly didn't want to stop playing until I got to the end and I was tempted to do a lot of side missions along the way. The horses were a bit of a fail (never around) as was fighting in the small corridors. Terrible camera angles meant I couldn't always see my character at all and he was getting stuck in corners and having the stuffing pummelled out of him while I blindly tried pressing keys trying to get him up and away from walls, corners or holes. The inventory was a bit of a mess, the idea of armour sets nice but it was too easy to dismantle an item and then when you switch armour sets find yourself left standing in the nuddy with only your bow and a small dagger. (Hehe)(Pun intended) I will say this. I would be replaying this game over and over if I had the option to play as a female. I wouldn't want to stop until I experienced all the classes and their armours/weapon combinations. I would also have been very interested in buying the dlc and/or any expansions. I think RPG developers should give serious consideration to us female gamers as consumers with spending power. I liked the game but playing as a male... there is no replay interest for me. Overall I'm glad I played this game though. It was fun!

number of helpful: 73 of 91 people (80%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
er 20, 2015
												+ LOTS of content+ Gorgeous world design+ The voice acting is bad (especially the main character's), but amusing at times+ One of the most interesting crafting systems (including magic) I've ever seen in an RPG+ Multiplayer has an interesting management mode+ Sailing mechanics are polished+ Challenging (due to some negative aspects, so take that part with a grain of salt)- Awful character models- Combat is clunky for a game of its generation- Combat feels unbalanced due to its clunkiness- Interface is not user friendly- Unoriginal and uninspiring plot and characters- Character creation with both genders and different races is only available on multiplayer- Game forces you to romance women and be a shameful womanizer- Horse riding- No tutorials for some important aspects, such as the hotkeysVerdict: This is actually my second review for this game. I feel like many people didn't understand my first, so here's a second one, more simple to understand. First of all, yes, Two Worlds 2 is not a polished game. Is not your Bethesda RPG (although their games are still very buggy, the mechanics are solid), nor it tries to be. TW2 is awful in many aspects, but it shines in others and it can be a very enjoyable experience if you can deal with its flaws. It does its own thing and it's good enough at it, being 100% worth the PRICE AT DISCOUNTS (I think I paid something around USD4,00 for the Velvet Edition). I wouldn't recommend it at full price, but for more than 30h of gameplay to explore such an interesting and beautiful world, it certainly is worth the bargain I paid for it.Oh, and btw! The DRM is not as concerning as some people put it. It is offensive, but you DO NOT have to give accurate information (I didn't and it worked out alright). Just put something random there, or skip it entirely (yes, you don't have to go through that at all if you don't like it). In all honestly, there are worse DRMs to be worried about out there, like Denuvo, whatever Blizzard uses in Diablo 3 and whatever EA has and will use.

er 25, 2013
												It's a pretty average RPG through most of the game with some interesting mechanics.  It offers my favorite lockpicking mini game of all time and crafting was alright as well.  Some awful mechanics like pickpocketing as well, the one quest where you're required to pickpocket I gave up and murdered everyone involved. I still got rewarded for "pickpocketing" the bodies.  I hear crafting magic is amazing as well but I didn't go that route. That said, after slugging through about 60 hours of gameplay, exploring the world and being rewarded for playing a terrible character, I reached the final boss.  All of your character progression is meaningless.  Regardless of your HP, fire immunity, and Melee skill, this boss will remove a third of your HP with every shot and remain airborne requiring either a magic affinity that is strong enough to damage the final boss but not strong enough to crash the game (I read this one on the internet as respecking is an option, it may have been patched) or the use of the ballista inexplicably placed on top of the bosses tower.  I tried multiple times to beat the boss but, after I reduced its HP to less than a third, it started using an undodgeable attack which always reduced my HP down to Zero.  It took me 3 tries to realize it might be a bug and abandon the game. Topware also has some aggressive DRM, requiring personal information like your full name, address, and phone number to enable the save feature.  I got a bundle with 3 Tripwire games in it, all 3 of them having the same requirements for personal information.

content:
ry 19, 2015
												Two Worlds 2 is a good game, but it is not a great game. I really liked the first Two Worlds and TW2 is almost as good, but there are a few things that really bothered me. The controls seem like they were made for a console game and at times it is rather difficult to have good control with mouse and keyboard even with customization. E.g. run, block and sneak are all on the same key, often causing confusion in the heat of battle (it is less than ideal when you are trying to get some space between you and an attacker and you end up trying to block instead).The game also clearly seems to give meelee fighters an advantage over casters and archers. My favorite play style is that of a stealthy archer. You can not do that in this game. Sneak attacks can only be done with daggers. Archery in general is rather difficult as the auto aim can not be turned off and it does not know how to aim ahead of a moving target, causing even a high level archer to constantly miss even low level and even slow moving targets from relatively close distance. It is a bit better with sniper mode from a great distance (where auto aim does not lock), but it is really annoying nevertheless. Also there is no first person mode, so your characters elbow tends to get into the way, blocking your view of enemies. Finally there were also quite a few bugs (dialogue skipping, and wrong shaders getting loaded occasionally, among others) that cost this game points.On the positive side, I really enjoyed the story (which unfortunately felt a little rushed in the end) and the many side quests all of which are well written and entertaining.  The crafting system is simple and fun. I loved the lack of classes and the freedom to customize your character skills. There is a lot to explore and discover, which is always nice. The graphics are quite good, though not outstanding for todays standards. All in all a good game for RPG players looking for something to spend some time on. I got it for a real bargain around Christmas and I would definitely recommend it for that price. I would not buy it for the full 19,90 it is costing right now, though. Better wait for another special again.

												Well i can surely say that this game is a really underrated gem.Is funny, huge and addicting.Yes,maybe is not an AAA production but is worth playing for sure.Combat system is pretty funny indeed, and the spell creation mechanics are something i've never seen in a third person RPG.There are various playstyles possibilities: stealth assassin,mage spammer :D ,archer or a brute tank vanquisher.Weapons and gears are in a good amount and the simple crafting system is well made too,with the possibility to recolour your armours.You can ride horses, play dices, sail and also PLAY DIFFERENT SONGS WITH VARIOUS INSTRUMENTS to get some money from the crowd in cities with a minigame similar to guitar hero. Man wtf you have to try this.Enemies are various and in huge amounts but sometimes are a little dumb. Fortunately a mod can easily repair this issue (read below for more info).The story is pretty long, not worth an Oscar prize but still enjoyable and there are tons of secondary (and funny) quests to do.The multiplayer is placed on another big map,different from the main game and you can play a good co-op campaign and pvp as well. Few players still online but luckily its not dead.But, if you want to squeeze the game to the maximum i suggest you to download the WorldMerge MOD from here {LINK REMOVED}http://www.mediafire.com/file/hb3qyopabhysz54/Worldmerge+1.3b+setup.exe .This mod will (as the name suggests) merge the single player and the multiplayer world  and quests in a single HUGE world to explore. It also adds high level brand new enemies, bossess and weapons, corrects some issues with ui, improves the AI and some other minor but useful tweaks.Last but not least my vote: 8,5I think that a real RPG player MUST try this game, at least when on sale. Really worth your time.The DLC Pirates of the Flying Fortress is another HUGE addition to this game. get it in bundle when on sale too.P.S. TOPWARE WE ARE WAITING FOR CALL OF THE TENEBRAE!!

number of helpful: 40 of 52 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
y 26, 2014
												I am playing this game and just can't get enough!Seriously, it is visually stunning.  I think it may be because they designed it for 3D.  Even though I cannot play it in 3D, I can feel the graphic design quality.Characters are mostly well acted.  The spell system is very creative.  You can combine different modifiers that custom alter your spells, but many times applying the alterations creates completely different spells altogether.The game allows you to quickly switch between three different outfits with the touch of a button.  I didn't think I would like this at first, but it allows me to play warrior, mage, and archer/sneak as the situation allows.  I have specialized gear for all three roles and it actually works.  It has really creative quests without being the go and fetch variety.  When the rare occasion of running errands arises, the story line has a compelling reason and makes you want to do it.  If you like old-school, dark, un-mapping (as in you need graph paper) dungeons, there is  a unique challenge in chapter one that lets you try your hand at it.  It is not necessary for the story line, so that is optional.I'm a huge fan of Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim.  It's no Elder Scrolls, but I would give it a 90/100.  Whatever bugs existed at release have been smoothed out for the Steam version and the game hasn't given me a single problem for over 70 hours of play.And it is huge!  I am in the middle of the second chapter with much left to go.  I am a person that does every little quest, so I figure I have about 100 hours left in this thing.I have no idea why I never heard of this game and don't hear people talking about it.Have fun with this hidden treasure!

content:
er 9, 2013
												A very solid RPG for the most part, with a crafting system second to none. It is not without it's rough edges however, and you'll want to play it on the hardest setting to help guard against your almost Godlike attributes too early in the game. The voice-acting is cringe worthy at times, but it is ok for the most part, and the ai can be extremely predictable and too easily defeated on normal and lower difficulties.The greatest strength of TW2 is that it get's more right than it get's wrong, and it is all packaged in very good looking graphical wrapping. It is just a blast to play - period, at least for me, and this alone should be enough for any fan of open world RPG's. Make no mistake, this is NOT Skyrim, but it is a very adequate and capable RPG that will keep you questing, looting, and killing, for dozens and dozens of hours.Get the Velvet Edition. The DLC is spectacular, and is almost better in many regards than the base game - just not as long obviously.Base game = 8.5/10Velvet Edition = 9.0/10Disclaimer:No animal or Human was harmed in the making of this - opinion.

content:
7, 2016
												Just finished the game and... well, now this is a hard one to review...Do i recommend it? yes, but...and it's a pretty big BUT.Overall the game is pretty decent, but it does have a lot of flaws.The first few hours i absolutely hated the controls, but i got used to it.The graphics are still quite decent for a 2011 game. The voice acting varies from very mediocre to actually quite well.Quests vary from poorly written from actually quite well.Combat feels weird, but once you unlock skills it's really not too bad and can be quite fun.I went melee, but i believe a mage could be a lot more fun if you look at the possibilities.The story is better than i expected, but it still leaves much to be desired.The ending also has some serious plot holes if you ask me.The open world is kinda nice to explore, but still too bland. I much prefer the worlds of the Risen/gothic series (games which are comparable). At one point you get a boat, it works well... but it's actually completely useless.I found the Swamp act quite fun and interesting, but the last act was a grinding bore.I could go on a long time about this game, but this sums it up pretty well . I went from "meh, wtf is this" to "damn, this game is quite fun" all the time. Sometimes i couldn't stop playing, other times i didn't know if i was going to finish it. You can feel the game was too ambitious and they didn't pull everything off.I had fun playing through it overall. If you see it on sale and don't have too high expectations, it can be fun. Just don't expect something like The witcher series. If you can see past its flaws, it's pretty decent and fun.But really, i have had rarely such mixed feelings about a game.I can't comment on the MP part because i haven't tried it yet.

content:
er 5, 2015
												<please ignore my playtime, i played abut 100 hours more during an internet downtime>Two Worlds II is one of my all time favourite RPG's. You can choose the way you want your character, and the way you want to evolve. You can become a mace wielding mage or a bow using berserker - its totally up to you! The playable areas are huge - very huge. You can scout and kill every area you like, enter any of the dungeons you find (except for a very few where you need a key for). The main quest line is very comprehensive, there are countless side quest and a huge amount of dungeons. While the story might not be the best you have experienced, it is still interesting and made me want to play more and more and more. The game includes a ton of different kind of weapons, spells and skills. Again, its totally up to the player to choose which of these he wants to learn/use. The combat is quite basic, but fun nontheless. A few downsides: - requires registration- takes away your rl- graphic pretty old for todays standards (still enjoyable)- the Multiplayer is a) dead and b) badOverall, i still recommend this game. (one of the best parts: The Labyrinth side quests. Looking for the tomb inside a labyrinth, only equipped with.... either a weapon or a torchlight. There is no light source anywhere to be found. You need to finish about 10 of those. Totally awesome)

												This game also stands out as having the worst DRM I've experienced. Its DRM currently blocks legit customers from playing the game. Having a steam key is not good enough and the user also has to activate the game through phone or online registration.That doesn't sound bad enough right? Well, this activation process needs to be re-done every time you change your hardware (e.g. replace RAM or install in a different computer). Still not bad enough? You are only allowed to re-activate 3 times in total.In terms of game quality though, I'd say it's second or third rate. It's not bad but also not something extremely memorable. You wouldn't miss much if you skip this game.

25, 2014
												Two Worlds II is a very nice open-world RPG game, Its a good substitute to Skyrim. Well, it obviously is not as good as Skyrim ,yet it has its own qualities, The unique quality was the magic system, where we can create our own spells and experiment with them, well that's better than learning a destruction spell by simply opening a book. It has varying landscapes such as A Desert, A Swamp, Dense forest, Asian city, Dark ruins , Islands. etc.  But the story is meh! specially the ending, the main quest is good as well as the side quests, but there are huge number of these kind of quests of many of them are fetch quests which tends to get boring after completing many. Tried the multiplayer a bit, its simple you can alone do a quest or with your friend, and there are different modes like death match etc.  I heard the multiplayer will be disabled soon, hope it dosent. I may have missed some points like fighting mechanics and crafting system which are "OK" at best! Its not an amazing rpg but it is a good one, and would have been a great one if the storyline was good. My rating - 8/10

r 13, 2014
												I have heard and read many reviews about this game and it has been very mixed.First off I will say I brought this game in a sale for £2. Therefore making this game a visually pleasing and fun to play. I haven't encountered any bugs, so, so far so good. The game lacks 'something' but cant put my finger on what that 'something' is. The keyboard mapping is confusing such as sprint and sneak are the same button. You need to stand still and press RMB for sneak and move and press RMB to sprint. So the keyboard layout it a bit weird. The prologue took 45 minutes to complete... I think 1 hour ingame until I was able to free roam! However once you get to free roam it can be very enjoyable, there map is relitevly large and you do get a horse about 3 hours of gameplay in.. The map doesnt require a horse though as you recieve a teleport pad at the end of the prologue so you can fast travel to locations you've already discovered.Make sure you keep up with you crafting and enchanting as you level up rather quickly, therefore so do you foes. So dont do a me and get slaughtered and wonder why... "Oh, I am using a damage 10 sword when I couldve upgraded it to 40 by now."Once you understand what you're doing in the game, such as how to craft and how to dismantle items to game becomes rather enjoybale. I havent played too much of the story to give a verdict, but on the whole for £2, I am really enjoying this game, I would say the game is worth about... £6. I wouldnt spend more than that, when Skyrim is only about £10 these days. (I have a MAC so this was my alternative to Skyrim).

content:
ry 21, 2016
												Massively addictive game. Cannot get enough of it, something about upgrading weapons, armor & gems just keeps me interested. The combat system, when you get used to it, is very rewarding and fun - while I still face some challenges I do feel like a badass now that I have properly levelled up and use the right gems, armor and weapons. Decided to go full warrior class so packed everything into strength and a little into endurance. Pros:1. The quests are WAY more interesting than some of the typical RPG quests with some pretty entertaining and, dare I say, mature storylines. 2. The graphics & sound is absolutely remarkable.3. Variety of things to do i.e. tomb raiding, fighting, hunting, horse riding, sailing, upgrading items, shopping etc. (keeps me entertained for long periods of time). 4. As stated in my opening remarks, the combat system is fantastic and if attacks are timed with defense the results are some excellent fighting routines. The enemies also have certain defense such as blunt force vs cutting damage so when facing say a Skeleton it is better to use a hammer than a sword. It is important to see / know what your enemies are "immune to" so changing weapons is a must to quickly end fights, especially when surrounded (something which the Witcher series uses i.e. silver vs steel) 5. While I am full on warrior, should I wish to switch to range (rogue) or magick (mage) I can use a soul patcher and simple respec my character. 6. The magick system from what I have seen (not experienced myself yet, is the best in it's class - more like Oblivion than Skyrim - where custom made spells are possible, only your imagination is the limit.7. The different areas are amazing from totally unique (lush islands with gorgeous flora which reacts to your movements, the savana, the deserts, the dungeons, the old ruins, the swallows etc.) each region feels totally unique with even the music adapting accordingly. Cons:1. You can see in some instances that the budget behind this game vs other more well know games is less, not based on sound or graphics but rather things like path finding for enemies which can be pretty dumb at times. 2. AI is somethings lacking (and here is a pro tip for folks in the early game) where the enemies have a limited chase distance where they simply reach the edge of this limit and will sometimes just stand there and take arrow or magick damage until they die. (Which was especially useful when facing the giant scorpions for the first time although I did feel a little dirty using this game glitch)3. Probably as a result of the first point but some of the caves / dungeons are reused but not nearly as bad as Dragon Age 24. Possibly a tad challenging in the early stages so kiting is recommended (hit and run tactics) I honestly cannot think of why this game has some negative reviews but have noticed that most, if not all are well under 10 hours of gameplay ergo they probably got smashed trying to button mash enemies. This game deserves a 9 out of 10 easily but not being a big budget & influential development house who can pay of the mainstream reviewers I guess it gets a bad rep.Get it and immerse yourself in something trully rewarding - you will not regret it.

												I bought this game for 0,52 EUR and I was pleasantly surprised how good this game actually is.Pros:- sophisticated game mechanics (magic, crafting, etc,... )- pretty neat graphic visuals, a lot of objects reacts to physics which is nice touch- magic crafting is really interesting and creating your own spells is fun- multiplayer (but have some cons), you can own a village thats a pretty interesting feature too- interesting locations, nice level design- you can have a boatCons:- controls arent that great character doesnt responde always that how would you thought- multiple actions are set on one button which leads to unwanted deaths because instead of running you character starts sneaking (but you will get used to it)- multiplayer - have no open world so you can only play adventures and after that there is not much to do ( there is a really lost potential in MP )- open world with restriction, You're on islands and you have to complete certain quests to get to the next island- not really interesting storySummary:Two Worlds II is a great game with a huge potencial that was kinda wasted. But still it is a game where you can spend many hours and having fun. Also you can try multiplayer with you friends which also offers a lot of hours of fun. So far I can highly recommend it.

Pity, that it's not perfect.I will not deny that I have a big problem with making a proper review for Two Worlds II. On the one hand, the game has a lot of annoying shortcomings which ♥♥♥♥ me off because they were already present in first part. On the other hand, over time, this game spreads their wings and becomes a tasty morsel for all fans of unusual quests and collecting a myriad of items, trades, alchemy, etc.. Some little things irritate (eg. A completely custom keyboard shortcuts, poor access to maps, dumb enemies), while others cause a banana on the face (ingenious minigame to open locks, interesting quests). Accents, both the good and the poor ones are distributed in Two Worlds II almost exactly equally. Thus, according to simple mathematics, I should have put the game five points. However, due to some undefined sympathy that I have for these series mercifully I will raise the assessment by one point.PROS:
An interesting questsSolid storylineDecent graphicsGreat cutscenes and videosLots of itemsAlchemy and craftsExcellent locks openingCONS:Poor interfaceFatal mapWeak diaryUnusual keyboard shortcutsAI errorsHorse ridingMinor bugs

												This is one of the most underrated games I have ever played. Before I started playing, I read all those mixed reviewes, but after approx. 45 hours of gameplay, I have to admit this game is awesome.  - great graphics (considering the release date, which is 2010)  - interesting main/side quests, often very very funny, with many twists and surprises  - cultural links related to non-game environment (e.g. Monthy Python and the Holy Grail - scene with the dark knight)  - number of activities you can do, e.g. playing musical instruments, crafting, brewing potions, purchasing estates, riding    a horse etc.Weak side of this game is definitely inventory management (and usert interface in general), which is absolute disaster, its chaotic and you have to click number of times to get want you want...However if you have enjoyed Gothic series, Risen series, Skyrim, this game is definitely worth buying.

content:
r 10, 2014
												Decided to give the game a chance after all positive reviews, and it was worth it. Overall well-executed and solid (not what you would expect of Two Worlds franchise, huh?) Though it has it downsides, of that below. But short summary - yes, the game is good.Two Worlds 2 in many ways reminds me of Gothic series. Free roaming, ability to climb rocks, ability to beat strong enemies, loot and steal everything, sensible NPCs and a right feel of progression. Not exactly there, but this is the best experience in open-world RPGs I've got since those times. On top of that, excellent graphics and animations (oh, pity that with such great combat animations game has such crappy combat mechanics!) and good story and side quests - you feel involved and always have a reason to intervene.Bad things. 1) The redundant key entering and invasive registration form (do not fill that, it's unnecessary!). Almost ragequite after some unsuccesful registration attempts; thankfully, continued. No drm-client, at least. 2) The game claims to be open-world, but in fact you are limited to plot zones, though they are large and free to roam. And there is next to nothing to explore outside of key locations. So it's more correct to perceive this game as story-driven RPG, but without rails and corridors. 3) Game is exploitable in a lot of ways. Kiting, click spamming, paralizing, poor aggro handling, patrol limits - all of that makes combat unchallengeable and boring. Having tons of health of the enemies doesn't help with boring. Heard there are mods that improve combat and difficulty level, but haven't tried them.Overall, the game was fun. Little grindy, but I don't mind to kite mobs a little - loot is good as a reward. Good controls, freedom to go, believable world, good story and quests. Good thing I have an addon, can experience the game a little more.And, of course, 10/10 for being eaten by umbrella!

content:
er 13, 2014
												While not the greatest game out, it took me by surprise. I purchased an RPG bundle because of a game in the mix that I thought looked enjoyable, Two Worlds II came with it and the videos looked alright.I have quite a bit of experience when it comes to RPGs and gaming in general working on developing my own games, software, etc.. over the years. If I could change one purchase I made at full price, I would've pre-ordered this game at full price rather than buy Arcania ( Gothic 4 ) on pre-order; never again from that company. Gothic 4 is one of the worst games, it is so full of bugs that you can't even walk down a small slope because you keep hitting invisible walls that stops you befor letting you continue. Two Worlds II is actually quite refined.I haven't played it in a while, but I ended up buying it 3 times ( One bundle had the standard edition, and the Pirates DLC, and then I bought another bundle with the Epic edition, then once for a friend because I enjoyed it so much ). I'd buy it again.There are a few downsides to the game, but they're so minimal I can't even remember them.This game seems very polished, I may have encountered a bug that I couldn't replicate. Gameplay is smooth, combat is simple when you get used to it, the controls don't feel clunky like Gothic 4 ( where you can spam pick-up and the character does 20 squats before picking up the item and where hitting enemies is a chore ).I'd rate this to be almost as much fun as Skyrim. The game has plenty of side-quests, twists, and more. I don't recall whether or not I cleared out 100% of the game, but at over 100 hours of time in game says something. The price I paid wouldn't have even gotten me a movie ticket, or a popcorn at the movies, at that was with buying it 3 times; For a game from 2011, it definitely plays quite well.If you think the price of a few coffees, a movie ticket, or a few soft-drinks is worth it, consider the cost to entertainment value for a game like this and buy it. If you're on the fence about the $20 price-tag, wait until it is on sale ( the bundle sites still have it too at a steal ) but at $10, it is more than worth it.

content:
ry 19
 I really, really wanted to like this game. I've tried playing it a few years ago and I tried playing it now. Turns out it's the most problematic game of all time. The gameplay itself doesn't seem half bad - it has decent animations, a great story and is deeply engaging but it's also very unpolished. It has a lot of potential.The reason why I  dislike  the game so much is because it's unplayable. You turn on the game and it asks you to give your serial number. Then, it asks you to activate your serial number by giving your very personal details such as: your adress, full name, email, phone number, zipcode etc. After you're done doing that, the game tells you to write down the activation key you received on your e-mail and then asks you to type in your serial number  AGAIN . This time it's a serial number for a DLC (only if you bought it along with the game) which you also need to activate aferwards! The game crashed multiple times when I finally got to play it and each time I opened it, I had to re-do the whole process of activating and typing in my serial number.  It's probably not very hard to imagine that I requested a refund.

content:

												Two Worlds II has one of the most interesting magic systems I have seen in an RPG for a long time. Instead of "This is your new spell" you actually have to gather components and combine in whatever way you want to build spells that do whatever you want. And air bolt can change into and slow fall, or even a rain of anvils. It is slightly OP once you have 5 or even 10 summoned creatures guarding you though... I mention this first because that was the most interesting part of the start of the game for me, and it's what I kept playing for. Once I got into the story, and especially the side quests, I found a world with plenty of humour and secrets including (but not limited to): Man eating umbrellas, undead lovers, giving impromtue lectures and gambling underworlds.

number of helpful: 41 of 69 people (59%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
y 14, 2016
												First, to the paranoiac reviewers fearing the DRM's information requirements: Calm your ♥♥♥♥. There was nothing requested that is any more than what your local pizza delivery place likely has on you.On to the review:Beginner tutorials are so uninformative that the NPC training you will give you a book in whichever skill (alchemy, spell casting, etc.) to cover the information the designers knew they failed to address properly to begin with.Stiff, halting dialogue from bad voice actors.(E.G. Thome the Scribe sounds like Droopy Dog with a Southern drawl.)Stiff character models combined with loose joystick and limited/ unimaginative controls make combat feel like a sloppy button masher.About half the mobs I encountered died too easy and the other half were damage sponges and others simply stood there until my firebolts killed them.Spell types (Elemental types, Necromancy, Summoning, etc.) require books to learn and then certain card types to combine into an amulet for castable spells. For instance, you could select an element card like Fire and then combine with a "carrier" card such as Bolt, Spray or Area Effect.Having determined I would play as a mage type, I originally thought this was implemented nicely but then I was finding next to no books or cards except random rotations on vendors, which charged an exhorbitant sum when and if they even had anything I could use.Screwy quests that are nonsensical even beyond the played-out fetch quests common to RPG games.Example:The first town I came to was Bayan.Within the first couple of minutes, I had three people beg me for meat, as there is a drought and all the villagers were starving.I give them each a piece of meat and one sends me to the village leader, who has a sick horse.She sends me to kill ostriches in the Savannah to gut them for the mint roots they eat to create a cure.She doesn't ask for their meat for her starving village, just the roots.Heading out into said savannah, I find green grasses and trees with numerous Ostrich, Warthogs, Baboons, Cheetahs, Rhinos... A short walk out I find white sand beaches with crystal blue waters teeming with fish... all manner of tasty things to eat out there but these slack-jaws are starving for some reason.But they don't want you to hunt for them, they want you to cure the sick horse so you can ride it past all the delicious creatures of the field to beg for food from the next village over.After curing the horse, I rode off for the next village of the mind that the people of Bayan didn't even deserve continued existence if they could neither grow crops nor hunt nor fish in the midst of such abundance.My grand quest was later cut short when I was sent to the Orc mage and a bug kept him from responding to my attempts to speak with him.Just how bugged other quest NPC's may be further in, I do not know but frankly I was not drawn in enough to risk investing my time beyond the first bugged subject to find out.Overall, I would say even if I had not encountered the bugged NPC, I simply found this game lacking.It is unfortunate, as it feels as though it may have been on the right track at some point and somehow fell short of hitting the mark somewhere along the way.If you do choose to get it, make sure it is during a super cheap sale for 85% off, because it is certainly not worth the $19.99 standard price if you are risking game/quest/npc breaking bugs.

content:
, 2016
												Don't let my time played fool you, I played the ♥♥♥♥ out of this on the Xbox. I would get into all the cool mechanics, the odd sense of humor, the vast amount of content, the crafting system, and the frankly insane magic system. But to be honest, I'm really just here to get something off my chest.For all of the game's vast scale, beautiful landscapes, absolute freedom, and good mechanics, I'm afraid despite all the time I sunk into it it never really stuck with me. The world never felt alive or like anything I was doing had impact on anything else. In short it constantly felt like I was in a game interacting with npc's, a horrific sense of disconnect that kept me from caring about anything that happened in it. It has almost a lonely feeling to it. In that sense I think it shares a ton with games like Sacred 2, where it feels like quality was sacrificed for quantity. Though, this game is WAYYYY better than Sacred 2 XD (Talk about a waste of time!) This lifeless world was really the Achilles heel that kept a good game from being a great one!Morrowind has its incredible world that draws you in with a unique setting and music, Skyrim has some damn fine side questing and full voice acting, not to mention some incredible lore to get sucked into, and TW2.... well, doesn't really have any of that. :/That is not to say that it's a bad game, as I said, mechanically it's a solid RPG. But if you're looking for immersion or a living breathing world, you would probably be better off buying something else. I really want to love this game because I like lesser known studios being successful, but honestly I found my time in the world only moderately entertaining. In the end, I think my sentiments mirror Angry Joe's, if you're a HUGE RPG fan who is waiting for the next big RPG and haven't checked out TW2, you should! It does a lot of things very uniquely and has its own personal style which is worth experiencing. Unique mechanics and a quirky, slightly self aware humor are just enough to keep you soldiering on. Just don't expect to feel very engaged, maybe listen to a podcast or chat over discord while you play. XD7/10 - Unique, a definite recommendation RPG fans burnt out on Skyrim/Witcher. Flawed, has a hard time making its setting engaging. Get it when it goes on sale.EDIT: One thing I forgot to mention, and why I went back to review this game in the first place, is that shockingly an update is coming out for the game soon. It makes absolutely no sense, but there was an announcement of a sequel and another upcoming DLC to coincide with an engine overhaul. I think it's pretty amazing they're still updating this game! Kudos to the developers for being so dedicated, it certainly has me very curious at to what the DLC could be! So if you do buy the game, bear in mind that apparently there will be an overhaul in quarter 2 of 2016... which is really close.

content:
ry 15
												TLDR; Great even with problems. Ignore the reg. form. Buy on sale.I find myself greatly enjoying this deeply flawed gem. While it's packed with errors like an erratic camera, clipping graphics, poor controls, randomly non-functional controls, poor iventory management, hilarious character movements, subtitles that don't match the dialogue, dialogue that radomly skips or plays on top of itself, and armor attachments that can only be purchased before you ever gain the right armor but never after.... uh, wow. Serious problems aside, it's really fun. The story is actually quite good, the side quests are fleshed out and entertaining with full characters and goals (like performing a recall on cused man-eating umbrellas). The game doesn't make a joke of itself, it's quite serious, but not without a healthy sense of humor. Character progression is an earnest thing, there are three major classes with different attribute requirements and a host of different skills to populate your skill bar. Melee fighting actually feels rewarding, though it can be frustrating and repetitive. Even so, enemies can have any number of resistances that will keep you switching weapons (and there is a handy hot-key for that) or changing up your gems to get the right bonus (and there are SO F****** many of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!). Archery isn't a joke! You get various skill-shots and other benefits, even a few melee treats for those that just cant put down their bow. The role of the mage in this game is better than most RPGs today, magic is craftable and dynamic. You make your own spells and determine the mana cost, the casting time, the power, range, speed, attack/defense, buff/debuff, area, how long it lasts, how many it targets. I mean, WHAT?! Really?! And the voice acting! Ah, what .... totally passable voice acting. Seriously, if you want bad voice acting play the first one in the series(hint: its awful). This one though? Not bad. Lets talk about the world: It's big. It's also dosed out like perscription drugs, so not TOTALLY open world. Chapter one nets you an huge explorable island and tiny home base island. Once you begin, all that space is open. Doesn't matter what's in it, who defends it, none of that. You wanna go? Go. Chapter 2 nets you another island.I'm 20 hours in and I just started Chapter 2. There is so much content in this beast, seriously, so much.So yes, it has .... ehm, serious problems... like, a lot. But it's a huge, thriving gritty RPG that really is an RPG, not just an action/adventure game wearing a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mask. This game is on sale all the damn time, just pick it up for like 2 or 3 bucks and profit for days. Hell, I'd probably even buy it full price.As for all cry-babies going on about DRM tracking and the registration process, IT'S ♥♥♥♥ING OPTIONAL YOU STUPID ♥♥♥♥-GIBBONS. I'm 20hrs in and I haven't filled out any forms, no one has asked for any information, no code was emailed to me to track my gameplay. Am I seriously the only one that remembers playing Diablo II or Icewind Dale? They asked you to register too; they asked for addresses, phone numbers, the whole nine yards. All you have to do is click the little box that says "PLEASE GO ♥♥♥♥ YOURSELF" instead of "YES, I'M A MORON AND YOU CAN HAVE ALL MY INFORMATION"What a novel concept.

												37 hrs into this game I have mixed feelings but still recommend it.The BadThe combat system is klunky and at times difficult. Walking doesn't take long but there are also portals and horses to speed things up. The world doesn't feel as open as the original game but its still very large and alot of leeway given once you get past the first few quests.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2016
												Heck yes I recommend this game. I actually believe that I would still be happy if I payed the full 20 dollars for Two worlds 2.So let's hear the primary complainsDRMUncheck the box, type in the code once. Done. No problem, no hassleVoice actingThe one thing I really love about this game is that every voice actor is different (or almost all). It's like I'm really in a living breathing world as everyone sounds unique. In the real world, not everyone is a great orator either. Some people are shy, some people mumble, some people are annoying, some people are goofy, some are awkward, some are confident. This game captures all of this aspect.Unlike skyrim and oblivion where every NPC has a golden radio voice, with imperfection lies a certain charm that can't be seen in other games. StoryI didn't finish the story yet, but it's not bad. Open world games aren't really known for great stories anyways.Side questsEvery side quest is unique, and there is an abundance of it. They do go in depth and there are special areas allocated just for the quests instead of plain backtracking. CombatOkay, there is actually a problem here. The swordfighting is clunky. You have to not press any directional button to initiate combos and sometimes the hitboxes are way off. That is a genuine flaw.Archery is wack. It doesn't feel satisfying and the hits of the arrow seem shallow.However, the magic spell crafting portion of the game is amazing. 4000 combinations of spells and great varying effects of each unique permutations make magic combat great. The others not so muchThere you have it. If you see it on a sale I would definitely recommend a try since it dips below $5 (and often 3$)

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Two Worlds II is only 5 bucks right now, and it's ♥♥♥♥ing worth it. I'm letting you all know, 3 days before the end of the sale.The story is decent, the voice acting works, it gets a bad rep for being a little different. Also, the AI is hilarious. Sometimes enemies brutally murder you, other times they are completely helpless. It's random and fun.The graphics are fantastic, the combat system is unique, often difficult to master, but very rewarding. There are no "classes". You just level up and choose where to put your points. You can spec in one type of combat, and you should, but that being said, mages can assasinate using stealth attacks and warriors can summon demons to fight with them. Rangers can snipe and shoot multiple arrows at the same time (and actually aim them at different targets), and the lockpicking system rocks. Mages MAKE THEIR OWN ♥♥♥♥ING SPELLS. Oh and the alchemy rivals that of the witcher and TES.It's open world, multiplayer (in an entirely different RTS game mode which is sweet), the graphics are gorgeous, the combat system shines, the loot system rocks, you can use a demon eye to float around and scout ahead of you.Did I mention you can be an actual Bard?? As in, you buy an instrument, and then sheet music, and you get to actually play it. Each instrument has a different style, which you play in a guitar hero like fashion. You can play the drums, the harp, the violin, the flute, and the guitar. The drums are the easiest, and the guitar is the hardest. If you play in crowds, you will actually gain money from the people, depending on your score. Being a bard is so awesome I've literally paused my questing and done nothing else but play, just to try and master it since the moment I discovered it.Seriously, you are going to want to give this B-sider a shot.Just beware, it's really hard. I play on Easy and it's still a challenge.

content:
er 6, 2016
												Four words- great, clever and fun. Forget the mixed reviews, this game is great and a gem. Old school and at the same time new and fresh.A million times better than the first game in every aspect, was decent but plagued with issues and pixel like faces.This game has great graphics, there is still a few issues with combat thou but is much better and smoother and odd bit of lag and a bit of roughness but runs smoothly and no slow down or drops.My main advice is to turn off the EAX Eniviroment on the settings section in game is pointless and causes some crashes issues on computer, game runs like super smooth and no crashes also you need to have a grapics card with PhysX since their is an option in game to use it runs much better and handles very well also turning off auto save helps alot. Also is a consule command the developers made to fix the camera issues in the single player mode google it but do it in the beggining of the game of a new game and save is best some peole have had issues but only do this cheat no other ones since it will bug up your game and have to unistall and download again.The spells skills and weapons, crafting are much better and user interface is nice touch, enemies are better and more varied, the areas are better if a little repetitive in some areas, the story is interesting and a lot of humour, dark moments, there is tons of stuff you can do in the game is at least 80+, 100+ hours including side quests , missions and activitys and also get the dlc pirate one adds something different to the mix and new stuff and content.You can play dice, double cross, steal, join stuff, and so many other actvitys you can do don't want to spoil them but some you cannot do in the witcher 3 and are different and has a touch of fable about it. You can hold two weapons like a bad ♥♥♥ and cut down enemies with death moves and the horse riding is much better, archery is better. This game is well optimised and supports most computers runs well on low end thou need to set some settings set lower but does not effect the experience at all. Note works best on windows 7/ 8- if you use windows 10 might have some issues which can be addressed by looking up on internet or youtube.Witcher 3 is a great game but needs a high end computer to handle it, this is the cheaper alternative to it but just not quite as good, witcher 3 is legend.Also after christmas 2017 they are updating the engine and tweaking some stuff and the combat also two new dlc expansions which will be great. The game came out in 2011 so is still getting some major updates. They have anounced a third two worlds game as well, fingers crossed it will be cool and not cancelled.My verdictGraphics 8.0Interface and inventory 8.0Story 8.5Game play- Combat 8.0 Spells 10/10  stuff to do 10/10 replay value 9.0overall 8.3/ 10Highly recommend especially in a sale, got it today for about 2 pounds with the pirate dlc you are getting a great value also dont need an account for single player only if you are playing online, playing this on single player, still learning new stuff and places have not even touched the surface yet.Great thumbs up.

content:
, 2016
												I really want to like this game more than I do. So many good ideas, so much effort, this game has HUGE potential to be something great. But no, for every good thing this game has going for it, there's equally big hunk of cheesy execution or strange desing choise to scale that down. After around 150 hours of playtime in Xbox version, I wanted to see if there's any difference in PC version. Though PC version is indeed superior, console version and PC version shares same strange desing of "Press 2 specific keys to do everything ever". For example; Mouse 2 is your sneak, sprint, defence, map- and enemy marking, and space acts as jump, use, loot, speak, interact, start event (lockpicking, playing an instrument) and backstep/dodge. Some of these doesn't work well together at all. When you try to raise defence in combat, make sure you're in complete stand still, or you'll end up running all around the place like Usain Bolt with his ♥♥♥ lit on fire.However, Two Worlds 2 is not bad game. Not at all. If you get through the confusing intro and get used to its controls, you're in for time consuming adventure loot-a-thon in a rather beaytiful, well made world. Yet still this is a far from actually good game. Like I early stated, for every potentially good thing this game has, there's somekind of bad decision in desing or execution.  I see the reviews of Two Worlds 2 are rather neutral, whitch suits this game extremely well. My overall opinion of TW2 is "Neutral". It's not bad or good game, it's "neutral". You won't lose anything trying this game out, nor there is any special reason to play it; it's "neutral" experience.The prize might be this games' biggest minus side. TW2 can offer you hours upon hours of exploring, but it reguires so much getting used to, that 20 euros for this might be just a little too much. Shall you get it for near 10 euros, do consider trying it out. "You just might find yourself a friend from most unexpected of places"

												I recommend this with caveats. I think I got this on sale for less than $2, IIRC. That being said, I wouldn't pay full price for it. It's fun for a little while though. It's better than the Gothic series, imo.I usually make melee characters in games like this, but the melee combat is terrible here. That's ultimately why I quit playing. The story was actually pretty good, but not good enough to keep me playing.TL;DR If you like playing mages and can get this game on sale, then go for it. You'll get your $2 worth.

content:
er 10, 2014
												Warning: Extremely long, mixed rant and story ahead. It doesn't show, but I've spent dozens of hours in this thing, I swear. I bought this... thing because Angry Joe recommended it to people who love really, really open world games. As a fan of Garry's Mod, Skyrim's WORLD (not the combat) and free-wheeling, massive games like Wind Waker or Mass Effect, I thought this might be up my alley. I'm not "terribly" pretentious when it comes to graphics, and I like European games. I thought "Hell, why not." Bought it at full price. With the DLC. I had no idea what I was in for. Joe, I love you man, but your tastes and mine are not the same. But first, the good. The World: You can pick a direction or a distant mountain or tower, and walk there. I love that in any game. But there appears to be three huge continents on the map: THIS IS A LIE. There is ONE continent, ONE small island, and ONE SWAMP. THE THIRD CONTINENT IS A LIE. Also, if you like generic Asian land, Savanah Land, and Swamp Land, then this game is totally for you. The graphics: The environmental graphics, while often repetitive, can almost be breath-taking at times. At full graphics I'm sure it's quite nice looking, especially the ambient lighting and textures. I particularly like the undead swamp, abandoned Asian town, wasteland, and initial savannah area. That being said, the character models are quite atrocious. While they weren't exactly repulsive, they were very, very ugly, in a charming sort of way, and suffered from an armor designer with tastes very similar to the horrifically awful taste in the Dragon Age games. Seriously, Bioware, shoot that desginer. Anyway, another somewhat bright spot in the awfulness is the spell design system. I love anything which allows you to summon creatures, and worked like hell to get where I could summon a massive army of skeletons to do my evil bidding, wiping out whole villages of hyena-men in a massive melee beneath a piercing bright moon on the blood-soaked savana. That totally kicked ♥♥♥, as well as wiping out outposts with hordes of rock golems, or my undead horde murdering fishmen in some idiot's flooded basement. There were some quite memorable side missions, the most well-done the very early on "Fluffy the Dog" mission. That was a quite excellently executed buildup and execution of a damn creepy horror level. Playing at 3am with headphones to hear that soundtrack in the final room (you'll know it) was truly nightmare fuel. Also that bit where the the guy was being buried alive, and the undead swamp, had really quite nice, stark imagery and fairly well realized concepts. I really quite liked those parts, when it was being marred by...The bad: And how much bad there is. First the writing: It is quite, quite awful. The side characters (and there are too many of them) are, for the vast majority, flat, lifeless constructs who dole out missions. I can remember a few of them mostly a corrupt embalmer, the grave digging guy, and the creepy priest. And some of the more major characters, the gay captain, the witch, the demon priest, the one British guy (?), the orc chick (Bioware relationship it most certainly was NOT) and of course the Big Bad himself. I actually was genuinely interested in his backstory, and to see how he and the main character were really very similar: both ruthless sons-a-♥♥♥♥♥es, who just happened to go down different paths. Definitely not a novel concept, or particularly well executed but I liked it anyway. Further comparing it to Bioware and Skyrim, I appreciate that everything was fully animated and voice acted. Not many games has the cajones to do that. However, that being said, the extremely annoying protagonist caused me to remember why silent protagonists aren't so bad after all: he never shuts his god-damn mouth. He dispenses a tiny pool of one liners upon dispatching his feeble enemies which RAPIDLY grate on the nerves during extended play sessions. That, and all the voice acting there is is EXCESSIVELY awful voice acting. Seriously. It is very very bad. But, in a morbidly enjoyable sort of way, I guess. You can always skip it if it really starts to ♥♥♥♥ you off (which it may). The other truly terrible bit of the story is the cutscenes: Every one of them is overly elaborate, horribley mo-capped, butchering-the-art-of-cinema awful. Seriously. These guys need to learn about a little thing called subtlty. And speaking of subtlty, the ending twist may just be the worst thing ever. Yeah, both of them. They just plain suck. Now to break down the meat of the game:      There is only one good class. Forget about the complicated spell casting system, because this is how EVERY, and I mean EVERY battle works. Summon deads. Deads distract enemy/form human wall. Throw the same basic spell 500000 times because it is the only thing that recharges fast enough until the deads vanish. Resummon. Repeat until target dead. Repeat ad nauseum with every single fight, and by that I mean the 1000s of enemies you will face in the course of this game. Utter lack of damage resistance means attacks from tough enemies often kill you instantly.      Archery is broken and horrible so rangers are stupid and don't exist.      Horse combat is utterly non-existant. I get that we can't all be Mount and Blade, but horses are worse that useless.      Only fighters have enough damage resistance to be worth playing, but their fighting is possibly even more boring. Spam attacks, wait for idiotic MMO cooldowns, and slavage armor so thick that enemy attacks don't even graze you. PvE is totally unbalanced. If an enemy succeeds in wounding you, pause time, make 5000 health potions, then drink them. The stats system utterly lacks subtelty. Put all your points in health and strength. There is absolutely no point to multi-classing. Dark Souls this AIN'T. Horrible boring enemies that make JRPG's slimes and bats look clever. Ooh, my club and I are SO scared of skeletons. I truly hate when ostriches, hyenas, boars, and rhinos, all of whom should hate each other, gang up to kill you. It's lazy. And you may have heard of the final boss battle on a forum. It is one of the most truly pahtetic, disgusting and spectacular fails of a fight I have ever seen in gaming history. I don't mean that lightly. All in all, it's frustrating, it's idiotic, it's droll, and it's very boring at times. But there are many points where I had fun. So I'm sorry, Two Worlds 2. I simply can't recommend you to the world. I can only say to those would be buyers out there: if summoning a horde of skeletons to kill a herd of rhinos sounds awesome, or an extremely clumsy approach to sexual assualt (shudder) is your cup of tea, or you LOOOOOVE horrible MMO combat: By all means. Play this... thing. It's your funeral.

number of helpful: 17 of 30 people (57%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												Well, after Two Worlds 1 my hopes were up. I should have known better.(note: updated 02-Jun-2016 after spending far too many hours playing it to the end)Two Worlds 2 on PC is worse in every way.  I'm barely to level 6 and I'm already annoyed as hell with this game.  When I got to level 40 or so, I was truly p i s s e d off at this game. Sheer bloody-mindedness kept me going, except for the ending. More on that later. On the plus side, the game lets you keep playing after the ending. I like that in a game.If you think that reviews should only be sweetness and light, stop reading here. It gets ugly.To start with, the graphics. Even on max resolution, it has the feel of a game stuck on 640x800. Limited view, huge character in the middle of the screen, everything that's wrong with a low-resolution view but at 2560x1440. Even fiddling with the FOV doesn't really help.Then there's the inventory tracking. TW1 let you put things where you wanted them. TW2 doesn't even pretend to care. No matter resolution (see above), the inventory screen takes up most of your screen. And instead of fitting more onto the screen, they just increased the size of the items. So you end up multiple pages of stuff you cannot sort to suit yourself, that you have to page through to find what it was they just plopped into the inventory.Crafting? Don't make me laugh. You can "upgrade" equipment, except you can't upgrade it very much to start, and by the time you have the level required to upgrade it to something nice, you find stuff that's better than what you can upgrade it to anyway. Then there's the material requirements. Each item drops 1, sometimes 2 of a material. However, to upgrade the full 20 levels, you'll need hundreds of material items. Which you cannot buy in bulk, you have to laboriously dismantle equipment, one at a time. And you'll never find enough of certain materials, and you can't afford to buy them, because by the time you have enough money, you can't find the low-level stuff to buy any more, even though it yields exactly the same "1 material" as the much more expensive stuff. Useless.Alchemy? Not bad, but really not useful. That is, even if you can find the ingredients in your pack once you have them. Sadly, there doesn't seem to be any order or reason to how they throw it into the pack. So you spend most of your time mousing over to see what it was you wanted to put together. Even then, alchemy really isn't that useful in the game.Fight mechanics are a wash. Initially you can't do anything, and you'll end up dying a lot.  At least TW1 gave you an option of dodging a lot when facing tough opponents. TW2 - nope, 1 or 2-shot kills is the order the day if you get close to the wrong opponent. Save. Save often. Because you'll be needing it. It's as if they looked at Dark Souls and went "hey, that's a great mechanic" without putting any thought into what makes it a great mechanic.  Later in the game you can at least block a good portion of damage. And if you time it you can sprint out of the way of a blow by the larger creatures. The fighting system still sucks though.Then there's the horses. In TW1 they were bad enough, with really poor controls and generally almost not worth it. At least you could ride and look around a little to check out landmarks, etc, so they were mildly useful. In TW2 they decided that "useful" wasn't something they wanted, so they took it a step further and made it so you have to constantly pay attention to a particular meter so you keep clicking at the right intervals to keep the horse moving. No clicky, no move. But if you click too much the horse throws you off. They effectively turned it into its own very boring, very long, and very annoying minigame. As for controls, it's almost unmanageable. A single keypress left or right at low speed and the horse does a 180. "Fine control" doesn't seem to be in the vocabulary.  As others have said, just up your stamina and sprint everywhere. Probably faster anyway.Then we get to the final boss fight. You've spent the entire game honing skills, creating armour, collecting potions - ALL OF WHICH will be completely and utterly useless in the final boss fight. They turned it into a duck-hunt game where the duck gets to shoot back. Really. Except the duck is a dragon, but that's the only difference. Your fire resistance? Doesn't work. 100% fire resistance? Doesn't count, you take exactly the same amount of damage as if you didn't have any. That in addition to clunkly controls (on the PC) make the final boss fight one of the most aggravating examples of shoddy work I've every seen, INCLUDING the boss fights in the pre-fix version of Deus Ex Human Revolution.One of the most disappointing sequels I've seen in years. Avoid this game at all costs!

content:
r 14, 2014
												So my first impressions of this game are pretty good so far. It's a vast improvement over the 1st in both gameplay and acting but even then the combat is fairly easy to grasp but tricky to to actually do when fighting more than one enemy. It's been set in a beautiful world however filled with different types of enemies and some side quests to keep you entertained should you decide to do them. I enjoy watching the clips which are well animated and sword fight early on in the game between an Orc and armour clad Knight was pretty entertaining to watch thanks to the way it was animated.VOICE ACTINGThe voice acting is good in some places and not so good in others with the main character neither being the best or worst of the lot but in the long run he talks in a grumpy whisper ALL the time with little or no emotion shown in his lines and, truth be told, listening to him speak caused me to turn on subtitles and skip the dialogue.Which leads me to my next issue. The Subtitles are poorly written, whether or not this was done in some kind of translation or just by sheer lack of proofreading what is actually said is sometimes a little different to whats written. This wouldn't be a problem if not for the grammer and placement issues I noticed so even though the actors make perfect sense the subtitles sometimes don't.GAME WORLDRPG's like this need a strong world to back it up, one that looks good and encourages me to explore and yes it is absolutely beautiful and the enemies in it are often well animated and nice to look at (all except the Groms which annoy me) but I felt no drive to go exploring too far off the road for fear of the extremely tough enemies that randomly plague the wilderness. This game has no leveled zones and, unlike Skyrim on consoles, the world does not level with you. At level 2 you could fight something very capable fo turning you into mince in less than ten seconds so choose your battles wisely. The first town you start in is located in the Sahvanna which is nice and has some enemies often not seen in RPG's like Baboons, Rhinos and other such enemies.COMBATCombat is easy to pick up. You learn it step by step in the tutorial sections so if you cant block from the get go, worry not because you still need to learn how. Melee comes first then Archery and finally Magic which people (including me) say is a strong point in the game thanks to the customizable spells. Archery and Magic are all auto aim but Melee is a different story, You need to think tactically to some degree though most enemies are a hack and slash affair.What surprised me was the stealth system of the game. You can sneak up behind enemies and stab them in the back with a pretty simplistic animation but this only works on humanoids so far as I know. Though I did notice a fair amount of enemies seem to be have their backs turned in the worst places such as beside a cliff. Why would you be staring into a wall of rock when your back is so exposed to an assisination from behind. It's alnost like they invite you to get that free kill!SKILLSSo there's a variety of crafting skills from alchemy to blacksmithing which work but its really hard to explain their function. Lockpicking in this game is quite simple but rewarding and the minigame used to pick the locks is both easy but clever.MUSICThis game has a really good soundtrack. The ambience to the scores during cutscenes are great in my opinion and really bring something good to this beautiful world filled with boring people. You can even buy an intrument and some song sheets though I never got to see if you could play them or not as I wasn't wasting money on it.As I play through the game I plan on adding more to my review.
