number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
6, 2016
												First and foremost if you plan on playing this game "Activate" and "Register" are two different things. You must activate the game by internet or phone with your cd-key, but make sure to uncheck the "register" box so you won't have to deal with the hassle of filling out a form with all your personal info.I had an issue with this game regarding lag or slowdown where the game would go from running smooth 60fps then lagging heavily then back to smooth. I was able to resolve it by opening Nvidia Control panel and manually setting the profile of this game to run using "Adaptive V-Sync", "Triple Buffering ON" and "Single Display Performance". It still slightly lags in parts of the intro where you escape the prison but overall fixes the major slowdown issues across the game.As for the game itself it has its charms and shortcomings. On the positive side the graphics hold up quite well in 2016 with max settings and environments have detailed design. You can have three active sets of gear so switching between fighting styles is easy. Voice over work is a massive improvement over the original game and feels more polished.On the bad side of things the game relies heavily on combat and it is very clunky and frustating. For example if you melee and move while you press the attack button for combos, it will break the chain. You must stand still for your attacks to chain. Smaller faster enemies will do hit and run tactics where they will charge attack and immediately run away a few yards, making counters useless. Then there are enemies that will swarm you and attack you repeatedly and all you can really do is block and run away. The game also throws in random enemies that are much stronger then the rest. Problem is you can't really tell which ones they are until they hit you twice while you block and kill you. The animations aren't great either. Attacks look like that don't have any impact and your character looks like he is just flailing his arms around. Auto target is extremely unreliable with a high chance you will be dislodged and attack open space.I haven't played too far into the game to get a strong grasp of the story but so far the prologue doesn't really offer anything special. The first bunch of characters that help you on your quest seem decent but the main character is annoying. I don't understand why he is so weak that he has to learn how to use a sword/staff/bow and he just talks way too much.I haven't run into any major glitches (ie. crashing/corrupt saves) but a minor one is during dialog between the characters the lines would get cut off and the next character would begin talking.Overall it's hard to give a definitive yes or no to recommending the game. I would recommend getting the game absolutely if it's on sale. I picked it up for a couple of bucks. It's a fun distraction if you are patient enough and give it a chance. However, if you had just finished games like Skyrim or the Witcher 2/3, you might feel like this game is nothing but mediocre compared to those polished amazing experiences.

number of helpful: 24 of 44 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												The first Two Worlds is arguably an abomination, surely it had a decent sized open world, a huge range of equipment and online to boot, it was executed badly and i really mean badly, it's one of the glitchiest rpg's...no, games of this generation.People were horrified to hear that there was a sequel to this foul game, so much that they thought it was laughable that it even got a sequel in the first place as well as the running joke of "two worlds two" but in fact, a sequel was just what this game needed.Although it was supposed to be an expansion to the first two worlds, reality pump and topware clearly saw that the first game wasn't well received and decided to improve upon it rather than adding on to it. As a result they decided to make a sequal...though it does seem to be a remaster of the original two worlds with the main villian of the first game returning in which you clearly beat him (ganondorf much?), that is if you picked the good choice. It's easy to say that this game is a lot more engaging than the first and you can see that they really worked hard on this game. The graphics for starters are pretty good, something you wouldn't expect to see after the abomination that was the first game, you can clearly see an improvement. Unfortunately this can make the game pretty unstable at times with plenty of lag issues (especially if you're playing a mage character).The game opens up in Castle Vahkmaar where you have been taken prisoner by the evil emperor, Gandohar (what a step up eh?) and you have to escape the prison where you end up on this small island and meet a prophet as well as a band of orcs, afterwards you are free to explore the open world...well not exactly everywhere. You unlock new areas as you progress through the main quest which may be off putting to some. One of the games strong points is it's questing. Unlike most wrpg's Questing doesn't always feel like a tedious affair, sure there aren't as many quests as most wrpg's such as elder scrolls but there are a lot less "filler" quests, most of the mundane ones being buliten board quests. Quests in Two Worlds 2 feel more interactive than most, though the main game gives you very little options in choice, there are often multiple paths/choices that you can take in side missions and many of them are engaging if only for the bizarre sense of humor in them and their creativity. Some quests may seem plain and simple at first however there are many twists and turns which may take you for surprise or they're just plain funny. Some quests can be pretty mundane but there aren't that many of them, thank god (seriously if you're going to add side quests at least make them interesting).The main story itself is pretty standard fare for most wrpg's, don't expect anything amazing. Two Worlds 2 can catch some players off guard though as it's storyline does have a few twists and they are well explained. put simply, do not play this game for it's plot. The main story does have some interesting moments and scenes however, just don't think about the plot much and enjoy your time in antaloor, pay the story no attention.The game play has improved from the first game and is similar to that of Diablo 3 but far superior (expect something Diablo esque with the game play) every element of game play feels reminiscent to Diablo, heck i even made some spells from the original Diablo in two worlds 2 such as immolation and nova as well as mana shield. Expect a lot of potion drinking and keep well stocked. Unlike Diablo however, this game is more open world style and isn't top down, so if you want a more modernized rpg with a Diablo like combat system, you've found it (heck even the health orb is reminiscent to Diablo). There are three different classes, melee archery and magic (Diablo much) and you are able to become a hybrid of these three classes should you choose to. Each class has their own set of skills available which you can learn in any order you please but before you can begin leveling up your character's skills you need to buy skill books to learn the skills initially (formerly learned from trainers in the first game) in order to use them and to level them up.Melee learn skills which can assist them in staggering the opponent and breaking guards, they can also deal extra damage, one move in particular allows you to deal considerable damage to an enemy but is only useful against an enemy who is left open to attack as is is easily blocked and hard to connect with. Using these skills also allows you to interrupt enemy attacks so you should use them wiselyRanged learn skills which can alter their elemental attributes and affect the speed and damage, most ranged skills are passive. There is a sniper mode however it is badly implemented which makes it useful only to pick off foes who haven't noticed you yet which is useless in many of the games dungeons due to their lack of space.There is also a "sneak" class however sneaking isn't effective enough to be considered a class of it's own, sneaking doesn't seem to work well in this game and it is simply easier to not bother with it.Mages are arguably the most diverse class as Two Worlds 2 allows the player to customize their own spells to create new ones using spell cards which give mages devastating effects. This is one of the games strong points as it allows you to experiment and be creative which is always good. the only problem is that their strength is limited, very much like in Diablo, unlike melee classes which become stronger and deal more damage with strength, mages do not get stronger with willpower as it merely gives you more mana and grants access to higher level mage skills, this is rather disappointing and in the later half of the game you will usually end up using ricochet spells simply because they are the best spells available and deal the most damage just so the mage can keep up with the other classes.The melee class is arguably the strongest in terms of base damage but they are required to use potions often, however the mage is a lot more versatile and can take out enemies at a greater range and it's spells can hit multiple targets making it somewhat more deadlier than melee. Ranged isn't really much different from melee other than it is long range. On paper ranged are the best choice of class but they most certainly aren't as they lack the complexity of that of mages and they don't have enough skills to balance with the other classes, unless you are best on being a ranged character i would strongly recommend against it as you will find the other two classes far more interesting.In terms of inventory and equipment, Two Worlds 2 feels a lot less diverse than the original which is disappointing, you will likely be stuck with the same armor you start with for a very long time and will be unable to upgrade until later. However the inventory system has made several improvements, items are a lot more clearer now on the screen and it is easier to organize, one of the few gripes i have about it though is that when you equip an item, it just shows a highlight marker so if you're not careful, you could accidentally sell it to a merchant. There is a new crafting system to replace the combine system from the first game making it far more balanced and you are able to dismantle items and save their parts for later to upgrade other equipment. There are also gems which you can socket into your gear to give them added effects, you can also combine them to make higher level gems using the fusion skill. You can also colour your own equipment using pigments to give your equipment the colour you desire, though not every equipment can be colored.Due to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ character limit, i'll have to cut the review from hereRead full review here: http://www.destructoid.com/blogs/Terry+309/underrated-two-worlds-2-review-268357.phtml

content:
y 10, 2015
												Keep in mind i have less than an hour on this game.With that being said, lets take a look into what i think of this game.1st. The tutorial feels too long- after what feels like a step by step guide to how to play, on a basic scale.  I feel tired of the  game already, from learning to running, jumping, how to sneak, attacking, blocking, finally after learning it all over with different weapons. keep in mind, you're learning how to do all this in a span of an hour. Its not entertaining at all, when they could throw in a press LMB to Attack followed & RMB to block.  Rather than there method of doing a full two cutscenes and a one on one battle to learn just that move.  If that's the case make a training room or tutorial button in the menu that ran you through it.  Not try to blend it in with the story.  2nd. The main character- Now this is my biggest problem, it kills the game for me, i can deal with a long tutorial but this will stick with me the whole game.  Its sad to say, but i hate how the main character sounds, like a bad guy in some old time bad film trying to like he is a terribly drawn out hero. making it  hard to follow a story that can not be take serious, its all like some big silly joke, that i did not find funny apparently.  With that said i want to touch on the character creation screen.  you get what, 5 options?  how large of shoulders, chest, and leg length.  what is the point of having a creaton screen when its really how tall you want your guy?  There is no female option since it would bother the story line, you can't change the descent enough hair style. 3rd. The combat- the very little that i player i did encounted some bad guys so to speak, and i had to fight them.  Nothing more to say than the fact i feel as if later through the game, ill be clicking, a lot.  Im sure it will get harder later on but for now im saying the combat is really badly done.  I tend to notice very little use of the movement keys during it since it makes you go crazy and turn your back on the locked on enemy. very big flaw i'd say.4th. Character animation- At points you can clearly see the mouths not matching the words spoken. Some movements feel as if im watching a kids show.  the movement looks really silly in cutscenes at times.  I could ramble on about a few other flaws but its not drastic enough to mention. So moving on, lastly what i find actually amusing about the game.1st.  The scenery- now i am a big fan of dragons, though there is maybe too much dragons placed every where.  I can't say i hate it.  Then once you actually get outside you can see a beautiful landscape, with plenty of vegitation.  Even the intro clip has an clever way of showing it.  No doubt they captured my eye showing the orc, i guess, fleet docking on the shores to charge the castle.  So a plus on that,2nd. Credit- In the short time of me playing this game i was able to find more bad about it than good.  Other that have many more hours than me could say other wise.  I do give them credit though its not a terrible game. Its not unplayable and im sure it evens out in bad and good later on.  though I may not ever see the ending of this potentionally good game.  Don't let my opinion stop you, im not saying the game is trash, or so bad that it makes me cry.  I rather not be treated like a kid growing up, and get straight into the action.  If you feel the same, i would say wait for a sale.  If you do not agree with me, feel free to go on ahead and purchase this game.  I just hope you get back what you paid for from it.*Also this is the first review that i actually took time and sat down and really said a lot about a game.  I appologise for anyone that disagrees and feels offended.  As well to those notice the many grammer mistakes, take note that i am writting this at 6:17 am in the morning from staying up all night.  thank you *

content:
y 4
												I love this game. This is the third copy of the game I've bought. It's an overlooked classic. Do you like b movies with cheesy lines? Well, this game has that kind of tone. The story really has a way of being playful and not taking itself too seriously. I remember playing this game while waiting for Skyrim to come out. When Skyrim did arrive, I thought the story was just too serious. Game play wise, TW2 is really only fun if you specialize in bows. Yes, similar the the Souls games, this is one of those games that you have to play a certain way to enjoy. It's a ton of fun to play hit and run with the special abilities of the bow. By the midpoint of the game, I would shoot a distraction arrow, then a freeze arrow if there was more than one enemy, followed by either a multi-shot or fire arrow. Crowd control is fun in this game. I love that the enemies don't scale in this game. Not only does this make the game more realistic, but it makes taking out enemies leveled higher than me quite fun. Don't miss this game. It's an underappreciated classic. Sadly, not many people gave it a chance.

content:
er 31, 2013
												An incredible magic and item management system, a beautiful, open world, and a roster of interesting characters that inspire empathy are marred to unplayability by bugs, broken DRM, extremely unbalanced mechanics, bad voice acting for the main character and about a third of the interactions, and a blase storyline. Pros: --The magic and inventory management is hands-down the best I've seen in an RPG in decades. This alone has kept me investing my hours in this game. Do-it-yourself spells and every item in the game upgradeable and able to be dismantled into the components needed to upgrade anything makes character building a treat. --Though the character models and textures look like something from 2003, the post-processing is very good, and the world is vast and full of surprises. --Between dice, grinding, pickpocketing, vendors that buy and sell at different prices, and a DDR-like musical minigame, there's plenty of ways to make money.--horses, boats, and fast travel - you can get to where you need to go quickly. It's almost too easy...Cons:--extra DRM! The Steam release of TW2 did not have the original CD DRM stripped, and the activation server is almost constantly down or unreachable. You will have to call a German number and manually activate it, or find the developer forum and email the head developer to have him manually activate it. This game came out in 2011, not 2001 - this is outright unacceptable, and if not for Steam's no-refunds policy, I would be screaming for a refund. (Glares menacingly at Ubisoft and EA for the same sin)--Yo Dawg, I heard you like DRM... Used one of the patches before the end of Chapter 1? Uh-oh, you have to re-activate at the end of Chapter 1! --But not in the GoG.com version. Seriously. --Bugs. Do not upgrade before Chapter 2, every patch breaks locked doors that require using cheats to unlock in Chapter 1. Some quests get bugged horribly, and some vendors never open up after dawn ever again. Save often, you never know what will screw up. Getting bugged through walls and off cliff edges, items skyrocketing because collision detection went insane, items that don't deposit into inventory correctly...ugh. --Butt-ugly inventory management system. It really is one of the most innovative ever, but damn is it ugly. can't move anything in stacks, have to click an "are you sure" dialogue, meaning selling 30 of something is 60 clicks, what is equipped on a different build is not highlighted in any one build, so accidently dismantling or selling another build's items happens. And Equipped items are not moved to the top or a special area, they stay scattered in inventory. --Unbalanced gameplay. Sword and board? You can take out most enemies anyways. Fast hits interrupt attacks, meaning slashing quickly disables an opponent. I've taken out things 20 levels higher than me. There's a mod to fix this, but seeing as the enemies and spells are stupendously unbalanced and grinding to meet an opponent between every quest gets tedious, it feels pointless.--The magic system is utterly broken. The magic system is innovative beyond belief - and that's its downfall. Random objects like anvils, stones, and barrells can be summoned, thrown around by force spells, and the like. But spells that concentrate stones toward a single enemy can one-shot everything. Meanwhile using missile splitting consumes almost the entire mana pool for a tiny fraction of the damage. Hypnotize doesn't work, altars are titanic and can easily wall off the innumerable small hallways in the game (but luckily don't summon for much longer than a minute). A lot of enemies are strong against or immune to most of the weapons and magic you can garner. Just use a mace and fire, because everything else does little to most enemies in the game, there's only a handful resistant to fire, and they fall quickly to a mace. And on top of all of this, until about halfway through the game, just because the player is commonly in the 5 digit money category, magic is expensive as hell. Invest at least enough in strength to use a good club as a mage, because you sure as hell aren't casting or making more than a few dopey spells until the second continent opens up. --Censorship. Plenty of swearing and violence, but no blood, no nudity, and even though there's a "sex scene", there isn't one - you just see her butt, she and the lead almost kiss, cut to black, wake up the next morning and never see the character again. Anticlimactic (pun intended). Armors can be recolered, so there's a decal system, but no blood. This feels like something from 2003. With The Witcher coming from Europe, I mistakenly thought a German game would be as no-holds-barred. Nope. Those Germans got it rough. If you want this game, and it does have a few things going for it, get it from GoG - that version has the independent DRM stripped out, and works better to boot. We all learn from mistakes; TopWare and Reality Pump have made some beautiful trees in this game into an ugly forest - let's hope they learned from this walking mistake.

content:
, 2014
												This game is one of my favorite games. It has so much free roam and the story was great. Every time I play this game I have so much fun. There are some minor problems, but critics tore it apart for these issues. I must say it was very unfair too, as these issues were not game breaking and the critics completely ignored a great game because of them. Cons-Everything above the mouth on your characters looks lifeless. In other words, your eyes and nose don't move (but your hair does). -The money system is a little messed up. (The best way to make money is by the "Guitar Hero" mini game.)-Changed the outcome from the ending of the first game. -The voice actor for the hero is a little bit off. (I liked his deeper voice, but I can understand why some may not).-The ending is a little frustratingReally that's about it, yet critics would fixate on one minor issue and act like it was something big. That's why this game has become a hidden gem.This game has so much going for it. There are loads of side quests on top of an already decent sized main line. The environment graphics are great! It looks good in all places, especially for 2011. There is lots of free roam and mechanics that you will want to explore.Pro-The alchemy system is fantastic-The "Guitar Hero" mini game is fun and addictive-The story is quite interesting-Lots of dungeons to explore (including a set of 10 dungeons that you can't use your map in and the entire thing is completely dark)-Great level system once again-Awesome magic system that has some real fun depth. (Look at some Youtube videos to see what I mean)-The whole game feels so original. -ONE OF THE BEST SOUNDTRACKS IN A GAMEThis is such a great game. I have finished it about 8 times on console. Sure there is not Skyrim free roam capability, where you can spend hundreds of hours on a single save, but this game has a solid run through of around 25 hours. If you are a completionist, you can add another 5 or so hours. I could rave on and on about this game.I hope the developers make another. It doesn't have to continue this story line, but their game is very addictive. I love their games. I wish this game could have kept that Old English charm the first game had, but I understand they probably wanted to appeal to a larger crowd. I absolutely love this game. It was a steal @ $20! Highly recommended. 10/10 easy.

content:
er 13, 2015
												I have mixed feelings about this game. The world is beautiful, and the main quests (and some side quests) involve actual C&C, and allow you to take sides here and there, which adds a lot to the story. There are often surprises to be discovered, when there is more than meets the eye to a quest giver or his motives. However, other than that the game suffers from almost every common problem seen in a fully open world RPG. For one thing, it's a lootfest. You'll be collecting a huge sack of stuff that you'll never need. Inexplicably, that includes a whole lot of buffers for situations you'll never encounter. (I really wish that developers would give some thought to the looting. Make it worthwhile. Give me something really powerful to buy. Give me a situation where I'll need a frost buffer.) Secondly, the story telling is choppy at times. I've finished the game but I wouldn't be able to explain the plot to anyone, just the same way I would be able to explain the plot of a poorly edited B-movie. Not that it's all bad. Sometimes the story can really grab your attention, especially when you're unexpectedly trapped or surprised to find out the identity of the serial killer you were looking for. The people who made this game can tell a good story, but they don't do it consistently. It's almost like the problem was organizational rather than lack of talent. An RPG with C&C is very hard to plan, and this game is a bit rough around the edges as a result. The story could also benefit from real professional writing, and some more complex lore. The lore of 2W2 is very thin and lacks a sense of politics and philosophy. The societies it portrays smack of modern day social norms rather than the humility, grit and fear of the medieval world. It's obvious that the game writers have played The Witcher, because they (loosely) copied some of its stories, but 2W2 lacks the unity of that game and its atmosphere and creative direction. That being said, some of the side quests can be unexpectedly deep and long, which was a pleasant surprise. The graphics, as I already said, are beautiful. The vistas are nice. The grass. The water. The shadows. Light shining between the branches. Aside from the nasty screen tearing, it looks better than many more recent RPG titles. Unfortunately, it looks like they were cheap on artistry. The design of everything is cliche. Your mage wears a pointy hat that makes him look like Disney's Merlin. The game features three continents and a number of smaller islands. It looks huge, until you find out that the biggest continent is used mostly for multi-player (which I admittedly haven't tried yet). The assets are reused in a subtle way so they don't get boring. For example, there is a university, and then there are ruins of a university in a dark place called the Swallows. They're almost copies of the same thing, but this is difficult to notice. I wish, though, the devs had made exploration a bit more rewarding. There are too many places where there is just a dead end or some nearly useless loot. The combat, while fun at times, lacks tactics. I played as a mage, and most of the fights in the game consisted of me casting a summon spell that surrounded the enemies with my summoned decoys that trapped them. Then I zapped these enemies with seeking fire balls. Really, this was a way of exploiting the stupidity of the AI, the fact that the AI cannot push over or walk over another (even much weaker) character and also the fact that the collision detector doesn't detect friendly fire and my fireballs pass right though the summons. In other words, 90% of the fights in the game are ridiculous. The combat system is also prone to the standard run back and forth spamming health potions abuse that is so common in this kind of game. It's made all the easier by the fact that your character can outrun anything. I should also add that the health bars, magic bars and any other bars in the game are about 2-5 times as long as they should be. A typical fight will require 20-50 fireball spells for a single enemy, late in the game. The magic system is a bit innovative. You can cast fireball summons, for example. Theoretically, you can combine dozens of spell cards into almost any elaborate spell. In practice, however, only some combinations actually work as a spell. If you play as a mage you'll be firing "guided missiles" for the whole game and not much more. The game adds a few interesting touches here and there. Your character talks to himself in some situations, and even makes fun of enemies. You can ride a horse, and even race it. You can buy a boat and visit one of the smaller islands (which just has enemies and loot in it). The alchemy system allows you to use almost anything that you loot in a potion. (Unfortunately, you'll be making mostly potions you never need. (As a mage, I didn't need the stamina boosters, accuracy boosters or even the magic bar booster potions.) Over all: a notch better than ok, 9/10

content:
r 31, 2015
												Two Worlds 2 is a third person, open world medieval RPG with better graphics than its predecessor and has slightly better voice acting but the the words are out of sync with the characters mouth movements. At max settings, the environmental graphics can almost be breath-taking at times, especially the ambient lighting and textures. The same cannot be said of the character models, which aren't ugly exactly, but they have wooden faces and movements. Wooden animations also plague the fighting along with terrible MMO combat and the clunky feeling of the controls. The spell casting seems weak and not very effective. The story is not original, its been done before with a few different twists here and there, but doesn't compel me to want to continue. Riding horseback is as slow as molasses, you can move faster on foot. It might look decent, but the underlying mechanics of the game are just flawed. Its clunky and glitchy like the first game, with a boring cliche' story. It has the same ridiculous Reality Pump DRM and you have to input a key and activate before you can play the game. They want your name, address, telephone number, DOB, gender, and e-mail address. It seemed extremely over the top intrusive considering its on Steam and I'm not going to play the multiplayer part. After all that, the game was...a waste of my time and money.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												While alot of the things in this game disappoint me, I have to say that this is the best magic system I have ever came across in any game, ever. (Seriously, buy this game, but only when it's 80% off.)But this cannot override how crappy almost everything else in the game is. 1. Let's start with animations:My character's running looks like a japanese schoolgirl running towards senpai (the kneecaps face inwards when running), his attack movements (especially spellcasting) are just off. The horses I guess are okay, but a little clunky in movement. 2. Menus and stuff:While the developers have tried to add a sense of fantasy into the menues, gold and blue don't go well together, especailly in this game. Their dragon thing surrounding the health bar looks extravagent. They should try a more minimalistic design.3. Quests: While the quest system is fine, the objectives and how you get there is often confusing and hard to navigate. Also there's nobody you can ask for clues, or even to repeat the quest dialougue. However, in some situations the quest navagation system is too straightforward, and I literally skipped through half the plot and beat the boss without really knowing the Story while I spent the other half of my time trying to scale mountains and get to the destination before realizing there was a shortcut that can only be opened after completing the quest there. While this might sound intruiging, I assure you it is not after 3 hours of rigorous scaling.4. Difficulty spikes:I don't know if this is just me, but there have been huge difficulty level changes ever since the start. The game expects you to grind, and if you don't, you can't progress. When I was in the swamp navigating my way through undeads, it took me ten minutes to kill 7 of them, and that was using summons and heals all the way through. While about ten minutes before, I was tearing through monsters in the last chapter easily. While this may sound like a personal complaint, I think TW2 should at least offer you a decent difficulty slope from chapter to chapter.5. FInal boss:I spent the entire game building weird magic spells that held so much potential they could be viewed as cheats, and the final boss turns out to be an FPS. 6. Voice acting:Don't turn on the sound, just don'tOverall, although I rated it down, this game is worth getting (ONLY ON SALES WHERE THEY ARE 80% OFF)The innovative magic system alone makes this game worth at least a few hours. But fair warning, don't expect much out of the game other than the supercool magic system.

content:
ry 9
												Amazing gem of a game hidden in mixed reviews.I have spent 49 hours on my first playthrough, finished the main game and I'm in the middle of the pirates expansion. The game is fun and refereshing in many ways. It has some of the most distinct personalities among many ARPGs I've played. They can be the stereotypical good or evil, but can also be treatrerous, insane, cowardly, wacky, sexy, hilarious. I took some weird quests that turned out to be highly entertaining. The game is well immersed in the morroccan (?) and Chinese cultures, and both are done very well and feel authentic. The game mechanic is unique to the series, I find that it has pros and cons but has generally functioned well. Pros+Very good quests and storylines that are often not politically correctVery diverse characters to interact withA few very attractive female charactersHilarious dialogueSkill and battle systems are better than Two Worlds IThe right mouse button has a dash run/swim which is very useful for impatient players like meAmazing culture and atmosphereSome degree of realistic elements (you cannot steal in plain sight and cannot aggresively run into people)Very unique magic system, you can build your own spells using elemental cards and modifier cardsGood selection of weapons and armour, robes and staves, bows and arrows.Con-The game interface and HUGE item icons look horribly unfinishedCash poor in early game and cash is overflowing near end game, need better balanceMap pointers for quests is much better than Two Worlds I, but can still use improvements Alchemy system needs a better way of sorting ingredientsCannot play as female character. Kyra:  I wish that big ♥♥♥ brother of mine can be locked up by Gandohar...Tips*By default, you are harvesting monster loot by opening its inventory screen, click on the item/or click on transfer, then close the inventory. This is incredibly slow and tedious. A better way is to get rid of these steps and add the loot directly to your inventory. Setting >> Interface >> Show looting interface >> OFF. Have fun!

												In the second part of the game, we must help our sister again. This time the main storyline is, in my opinion, much more interesting than in the previous production. Discovering facts from the past of the main villain makes one want to finish all chapters. The world is divided into islands which are geographically, biologically, as well as culturally distinct from each other: we can travel through "Middle East" and "Chinese" cities as well as visit "Medieval" village surrounded by swamps. Each of the island is full of secondary quests. The game has good music including a song, as in the first one.  Sailing in a boat between islands is relaxing experience after hours of fighting. Plot holes, especially at the end of the story, are the main negative elements of the game.

So I decided to buy the game and try it out and sure enough, I am greeted with one of the worst intro to games Ive ever seen on Steam.First, you log on and it asks you to enter the 16 digit serial key. Bare in mind, I've NEVER had to do this on Steam. Never. Steam always provides it, but it doesn't seem to come up.Second, after you put in this code which, really wasnt that big of a deal, now you have to activate your account? Wait what? Is this an MMORPG all of a sudden? You have to put in your name, address, state, DOB, e-mail. Just to play a Single player game. I'm surprised I dont have to put in a Credit Card number too with some screen telling me that "Note: Your card will not be charged! This is just to have you on file!"Third, ITS A BAD GAME. Don't waste your time with this aggressive nitpicky activation garbage just to play a bad RPG that shouldnt even exist.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
20, 2015
												First impressions:Two Worlds 2 is an RPG, similar to Gothic, Elder Scrolls and Risen. It stands out for it’s kick-♥♥♥ magic spell system. They’ve come up with this do-it-yourself magic spell card engine which let’s you build custom spells. It’s fun and original - first time I gave the wizard-character a try in an RPG.The game did a lot of things right and overall left a user-friendly and positive impression. Pros:+ Ok graphics+ Cool character, kinda reminds me of Danny Trejo. Also, he has those small comments upon interaction which sound smart and help improve his personality.+ Super fast loading time.+ Ability to save custom outfits in case you need to quickly change from wizard to warrior etc. This should be a genre standard.+ Mobile teleport platforms was a very good idea.+ User-friendly mission guide that gives you good overview of where you have to go and what you have to do.+ Huge variety of enemies throughout the game.Unfortunately there were those tiny mistakes that could and should have been fixed and improved before the game came out. Those were mainly issues that made the game feel a little immature and green, as if the development team consisted of professionals and amateurs and everyone got to contribute. Cons:- I never got the idea behind the name ‘two worlds’. Was it supposed to be something metaphorical? I played as a wizard who looked a lot like Gandalf in his younger years and the events were taking place in a savanna/jungle so more than ‘two worlds’ the game felt like Gandalf’s Safari Adventures. - Major flaw: the game crashed left and right. I could count as much as 5 crashes in 2 minutes. Then again that truly helped me appreciate the quick loading times.- Character design was way over the top. All those ridiculous, skimpy armors and gosh, those shoulder plates!- The Voice Acting ...this was such a major one. When you take a person with a normal voice and tell him to imitate a funny sounding person, then it sounds like a normal person is making funny sounds. That happened throughout the game. Voice acting in this game might be the worst I’ve ever experienced. - The script/ writing. The dialogues were long and dead boring, the story was unnecessarily complicated + there were completely obsolete characters. It all comes down to really bad game script.- Something that’s easily forgettable once you’re in-game, but how they implemented Digital Rights Management in this game was not acceptable. The kind of information they asked before I could play the game made me feel very reluctant and extremely uncomfortable.- NPC movement speed compared to animation was out of place. - The great paradox of Two Worlds 2 is the ability to outrun rhinos and panthers even though your stamina is depleted after 100 meters of sprinting.- Swift moving around in combat makes the enemy AI go crazy, they will get stuck behind obstacles and go into attack mode some 5-6 meters from you. - Banal, unrealistic female characters - a demoness, a vixen and a damsel in distress.- Battles boil down to how fast you can click the mouse button.Verdict:The Cons list became quite long but let yourself not be discouraged by that, those were just minor flaws, all except the DRM issue which kills the gaming world and violates human rights. Overall it was a very positive experience and introduced many new original elements that I'd like to see become a genre standard.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
13, 2016
												This game has the most boring and cringe worthy story of all ♥♥♥♥ing time. I hate the characters I hate the plot I hate the fact that orcs are good guys (Cause they are evil in every other universe other than WoW but I dont like WoW so whatever) I hate the character you play as. BUT, this game has some mechanics that really outshine its competition. The magic system is the best and most fun to use I have ever seen, as you dont just learn spells, you craft them, and if you invest a lot in magic, you can have multi-stage spells. For instance, I made a spell that starts as a powerful homing fireball that blasts an aoe of fire that spawns a jackel-man warrior on impact. I also made a spell that turns me invisible and allows me to walk on water, which is very useful in the late-game. The fact that you can summon an undead army to fight your foes is awesome! Especially when you are going up agaisnt a large group of enemies, because its like two clashing armies in some battles. TO BAD THE GAME CANT HANDLE THIS AND ♥♥♥♥ING CRASHES EVERYTIME A BIG BATTLE STARTS. The biggest problem with this game is that for every awesome badass thing this game has to offer, there is always something holding it back. The game crashes whenever a big battle starts, the story campaign forces you to do quests in an area of a big open world map before going to the next section of the world, dialog options dont matter because you are either accepting or declining the quest given other than in one instance that i can remember, and you fail if you choose the one I would have chosen in real life, as the only evidence against the accused is the supposed victims accusation and nothing more. Aparently thats enough to condemn this man or else the victim KILLS THEMSELVES. Great, I love being wrong for keeping a cool head in tragedy and not calling for the death of a man based on the charges alone AND NOTHING MORE. The armor customization is cool but is held back by a lack of options for dye colors and what can be worn with what, relatively interesting side quests are held back by a lack of explanation or closure. "These gaurds are so devout that they stuck to their posts, even AFTER DEATH!" Why are they still gaurding an abandonded factory in the middle of nowhere? Who cares just kill them! Having a boat and being able to sail around is pretty cool, too bad there is very little to see out at sea. People keep calling you handsome but you never score. The biggest land mass in the game is unaccesible FOR THE ENTIRE GAME AND YOU CAN NEVER ACCESS IT EVER. This game has some truly great ideas, the alchemy is strong and worth a damn, the magic is more than your genereic RPG main-character-learned-fireball! system where YOU the PERSON are learning how to craft truly awesome spells. And its a pretty good loot fest, and has some monsters I have never seen before that are original and not copy-pasted in the game. But again, these things are held back by problems seen for the prepevious game, its buggy (which sometimes actually make this game better as you can bypass some of the BS world checkpoints), the story and characters SUCK, and the combat is just ridiculous. It seeems like there are bits of this game wanting to really break the mold and just go crazy and take you on a wild ride, but the rest of the game is to afraid to take any chances or do anything interesting. So to conclude I would recomend this game to you for around 25$ or 30$ at the most, cause your enjoyment really depends on how much you enjoy magic and how much you can stomach this games short comings. If these people make a third installment I personally will buy it, cause I can almost feel this game trying to spread its wings and sore above most of its competetors. Hell, if they ditched the crap story and just said: "Make you and do what you want, experience this world!" and made this game function properly, I feel like that game might even beat out Bethesda's ELder Scrolls next game. Imagine, a game where you had the potential to be the most baddass mage who could make his own guild and RULE THE WORLD whithout being hampered by some BS story where you take orders left and right and basically be the errand boy of people you could EASILY kill at your whim. I would love a game that just says: "There is a huge, baddass world out there just waiting for you, GO GET EM TIGER!" I dont care who makes that game, I will buy it, and I wouldnt care if was more than 60$, if it delivers, I would still buy it.EDIT: This game crashed 15 times in 15 minutes during what could have been an epic battle between my ubead soldiers and a tribe of jacklemen.

content:
y 25, 2016
												Two Worlds was an interesting fantasy game, it was flawed but there were objects and systems in it that I really liked. Two Worlds 2 picks up a little bit after where the original left off and you are still just as much in the dark as the first one. Gandohar is doing somethin evil, but his motives are never really explained nor what has happened in between the two games.One thing that really bugs me about this game is that a lot of the things in this game have to be worked around and serve no purpose other than to make things needlessly difficult. For example, spell usage in the previous game was a useful way to mix swordplay with elemental attacks and healing to save you from death. In this game spells can only be used with a staff and the system for using spells in convoluted and requires lots of study and experimentation. Spell cards can be bought, but they are ridiculously expensive.Movement is blockier, akward, and running is hard to control or stop. Horse riding can help you cover long patches of land quickly, but the horse is hard to turn and jump with, and you can easily lose track of him while on foot.Finally, the overlay system of the last game (which let you combine two of the same weapons or armor pieces to make an improved version) is replaced with a crafting system where gear is improved with materials found by breaking down other gear. While not worse than the old system, it's still another unessecary thing to worry about.Overall, I would reccomend you play the first game before you play this one otherwise you may be unhappy with the systems and mechanics and not give it a try.

												Two Worlds 2, everytime I come back to it it somehow can impress me all over again, from all the RPG mechanics to the amazing looking vistas. This is a truely wonderful RPG experience.The first time I played it which was a few years ago, I was but a meer console baby, and as soon as I played fifteen minutes I dropped the game. What a terrible choice, a few years later I decide to pick it up again and I was blown away how much sheer diversity there is in the playing styles to all the armor and loot choices. The game really does make you feel like an adventuer, from exploring crumbling caverns to a long harsh Savannah Desert to deep forests.The combat is a mixed review on my part, I feel as though they could have included a better control system even with a controller. Left trigger is sprint, left trigger is sneak and left trigger is draw. A bit silly due to all the playing styles they really had to fit alot of things in, the combat on the other hand features between an arrowing slinger Archer to a brave Warrior or just a spellslinging Mage. Even though the melee and ranged combat is pretty flawed, it really makes up for it in the spells. The ability to craft different combinations with three different enchantments, from a massive vortex to a chilling icebolt.Over all, this game has really grown on me as a RPG - I suggest this to anyone who is looking for a good RPG.

content:
y 27, 2015
A pretty good Action/RPG containing an immense world with many adventures and places to discover.The single-player mode can be a little bit confusing in the beginning if you haven't played the prequel before. The controls and menu system was a little tricky for me, because I was used to Bioware and ElderScrolls games. Pros - Vast Single-player world.- Finely optimized, nice graphics.- Clever and fun magic/spell system.- No classes, you can shape your character to your own taste.- Multi-player community is really friendly. The guys there helped me a lot.- Co-op adventures can be played with up to 8 players! (Tougher enemies > more XP)- Many game modes in multi-player. Defense, Adventure, Duel, CTF etc.- Both in single and multi you can build and maintain your own village.  Cons - Not many co-op adventures and because of this multi-player can be boring after a while if you're not intereseted in pvp.- Physics have some bugs, can be annoying sometimes- The use of bows are really confusing- Almost every attack you suffer incapacitates you, but your attacks won't do that to enemies. Really annoying!- You can upgrade your gear many times, but you can't buy resources for this - like in Skyrim. You obtain stuff only by dismantle found or bought weapons and armor.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 4, 2015
 Positive + In terms of graphics, this ends up being a positive mark for the game. While character models and animations leave much to be desired, some of the environments (and the textures themselves) are really well-detailed, including ancient Asian and Egyptian architecture, as well as some impressive lighting that is determined to showcase the best the graphics have to offer+ Taking around 10 ½ hours to complete the main story (on Medium difficulty) is a good length in and of itself. But, if you really want to explore everything the game has to offer, you can easily net yourself another 20-30 hours of gametime. There’s no shortage of side-quests to complete+ There’s an abundance of different (though basic) gameplay mechanics; from upgrading weapons via blacksmithing, to alchemy, lock picking (surprisingly one of the most fun lock picking minigames I’ve played), and even some stealth mechanics thrown in to offer some variety. And, while the combat is relatively simple, there’s a good variation of skills to use (including ones for melee and ranged weapons, as well as spells) that prevent the combat from being too repetitive or bland, and allows you to tweak your character to fit your preferred playstyle. Negative - Easily the biggest negative for me is the lack of difficulty scaling. What this basically means is: if you want to play the game just for the main story, you will have an exceedingly difficult time doing so (even on Medium difficulty). The game will force you to resort to cheap tactics in order to beat boss battles/hard encounters and run past most of the enemies throughout the dungeons, unless you complete side-quests (which there are plenty of, but I don’t think it’s fair to force the player to complete them in order to have a fair chance of defeating the main obstacles the game throws at you). This ends up making the game artificially difficult, as no matter how well you utilise or level your skills, you will have a needlessly problematic trek towards the end credits if you don’t complete optional content (unfortunately the final boss itself is rather awful as well, so I wouldn’t blame you if you felt like quitting before reaching the end)- While there are plenty of side-quests to complete, the world itself--which may be big in scale--doesn’t really encourage exploration. There are simply vast masses of land that don’t contain any meaningful sights nor secrets worth discovering, which is a shame because the world itself is quite pretty- Again, like the first game, the wooden voice acting and weak sound design in general don’t make much of an attempt to immerse you into the world of Antaloor; though I will admit, the music itself is very charming and partially redeems the sound overall - Lastly, the story itself is predictable and forgettable; no interesting main characters and nothing that hasn’t been done before. Worth Mentioning • Though people claim the game has severe DRM, all it really is is putting in a serial number, and using online activation to verify your purchase (which only needs to be done once). It literally takes only 30 seconds to do so... unless you forget to uncheck the checkbox which tells you to register (which makes you enter personal details, but this isn’t required to play the game at all). But, if you hate ‘DRM’ in any form (excluding Steam DRM), then by all means don’t bother purchasing the game. Verdict “Two Worlds II starts off as a rather clunky experience. But, once you start getting into the swing of things, you will find yourself enjoying the game more and more as you delve deeper into it. While the game is just a basic open-world RPG, with both poor and good qualities mixed together, overall this and the first game have an undeniable charm that makes them memorable (and admittedly better than they deserve to be). With some more polish here and there, this game could be even better than I’m giving it credit for.” 7/10 TJBs

Magic customization is cool, but doesn't matter when 90% of the time you must glitch enemies through terrain to even be able to hit them.  In case you were wondering, yes I am that serious.  I rarely write reviews for games, but the combat, pathfinding, bugs, and general gameplay on this game are so attrocious that I would hate for anyone else to purchase it.  I really remember two worlds 1 being much much better than this is.  Not that it was great but I found it moderately enjoyable.  The enemies and quests are so bug-ridden in this game that it is not.  In this game enemies often stop moving completely just to be repeatedly shot by arrows.  Believe me, I enjoy a good B-rated game.  But not this, it isn't nearly as fun as tw1 and even that wasn't that great.

er 17, 2016
												Two Worlds II is a hidden gem with a few scratches on the surface. Poorly constructed combat and awful controls are the only glaring problems with the game. Get past that, though, and you'll uncover incredible lighting, decent graphics, an excellent magic system, a beautifully diverse game world, lots of quest variety, a fantastic soundtrack, and a decent story. With gameplay that can last you about 50 hours or so, it's unfortunate that so few gave this game a chance. I definitely recommend it to Action RPG fans!

content:
13, 2016
												It's not as clean and polished as most other games, but it has a lot of great elements taken from games such as Skyrim, Diablo, Assassin's Creed, and many others. It had (and still has with this year's [2016] big update coming) the potential to be a better game than all the rest surprisingly, but it seemed to fall short in many aspects. I love the items, map, NPC interactions, enemies, and especially the leveling and magic systems! Plus the difficulty feels just right and the game is seriously funny as it never takes itself too seriously, but the combat completely falls short in it's glitchiness, and story falls far, far, FAR short as it's simply complete garbage.... but still, the core game has a sort of magic to it that keeps you playing and enjoying it overall.You can see I've had to say "but" a whole lot in this review after trying to praise Two Worlds II, BUT if you can overlook some of it's shortcomings, and enjoy the parts where it shines, it's a very fun game for $21.99.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2016
												First, the game does have its issues.  Nothing like running down a hill and taking enough fall damage to kill you, but if you press jump you can take a 50 foot jump with no damage.  Just weird and inconsistent.  And yes, you have to enter a key when you first run the game or get a DLC for the game, which is unusual and annoying at this point in time.  That being said, the land is interesting and fun, there are tons of creatures, a lot of flexibility with the story line but the biggest plus is the magic system.  You make your own spells from components and rearange the components later to suit other needs.  For instance I have created spells that shoot out a spray of missiles. The missiles blind when they hit and summon undead warriors where they land.  Another shoots a huge spray of fire missiles which bounce around filling an area with fiery death.  I've used water walking and feather fall to weasle my way into areas that, later, I realized I was supposed to get to later in the game, yet I was able to make it work.Another oddity of the game, which from my perspective, Im not sure is a plus or a minus is the multiplayer.   It has multiplayer, but unlike other games where you play the same game single and multiplayer the multiplayer game is a different game.   Same game mechanics but you gather in a city, and choose a storyline that has nothing to do with the single player game, gather your comrades and play through that scenario.  On one hand its extended, unique game play.  On the other you cant use the single player character you built up, you dont get to explore the extensive single player world and questlines with a friend and the multiplayer game has much less content.  I can still say I've had fun in multiplayer and built up a powerful multiplayer character, but its worth noting that when you read that the game is multiplayer its probably not executed the way you probably think it is. All in all I've enjoyed it an think its a game well worth exploring.

content:
6, 2014
												This game is a mixed bag to tell the truth. Massive amount of content which promise hours and hours of gameplay, that is if one is willing to overlook its flaws which make the game a chore to trudge through. Customization is fair although the single player campaign isn't as lenient and exciting as the multiplayer character customization. Combat is clunky at best and weapons dont have any weight to them, although the magic system makes up for it that is if the player is willing to be a mage above all else. There are a variety of enemies to fight against which makes combat refreshing despite the controls and horrid physics. Character models look stiff and unfinished although at times they look great (in cutscenes), maybe its the fact that the arms look really weird and unfinished. Voice acting is bearable most of the time although your character can get annoying at times. Action is pretty much average to say the most, story is decent, Two Worlds II isn't exactly going to be everyone's cup of tea but its a decent game in its own right. 6/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												After hearing how horrible this was in all the years since its release, I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by this game. The voice acting is terrible, the combat is weird at times, and the context sensitive keys seem like a useless relic from console porting, but this game feels like the first Witcher, but without timed button press combat. so far much of what I have been doing is following a tiny main quest thread and running around killing monsters for people. I'm a total sucker for games with a crafting system, and even though this one is kind of bare bones(only item improvements; no actual item creation) it is still fairly rewarding. Another huge bonus somewhat related to this is that your armor actually changes when you equip new pieces. It isn't just 8 reskinned versions of the same armor ala Dragon Age: Origins. Every set so far feels like a unique and interesting enough looking piece of armor. Cloaks abound, with decent cloth physics, though I have seen one scene where the cloak was draped across a character's body the wrong way, clipping through his chest and draping over his front. I'm playing this game with the Worldmerge mod, since I have the DLC and it is reportedly more immersive this way. The game looks amazing with DX10. Whenever I launch it with DX9 it just looks fuzzy in comparison. There is a huge amount of realistic plantlife dotting the landscape. It makes grassy fields in skyrim look like child's play. After putting it off for such a long time, I feel absolutely blown away by this game.Edit: the ending is a little confusing and kind of a let down. Just...be prepared for nearly nothing to be explained.

content:
6, 2015
												Positive:-A lot of people are complaining about the activation. They make you put in a lot of information that they should not need to know (full name, address, ect.) which is annoying BUT you can just put in fake information and you are good. I said that I lived in "nowhere". -Free roam, open world; the environments are good-Lots of side quests-The story is... okay; not great, but not bad either-I got about 40 hours of gameplay (with every side quest completed)-Voice acting overall is okay. Dialogue is sometimes cheesy, and a couple character voices were ridiculous; but they aren't immersion-breaking. Negative:-Had to rebind almost EVERY single key, because for some reason E = jump and SPACE = activate, as well as other horrible binds. Some important things aren't even bound to a key at all with default settings.-Combat is not always very responsive. I will press the key to block.. he won't block. release the key, do it again, still wont block. Annnd now i'm dead because he wouldn't block.-Drinking potions is not always very responsive. "drink a health potion... i'm telling you to drink a health potion.. i've spammed the key about 12 times now..." annnd now i'm dead because he woulnd't drink a potion.-Sometimes dialogue will skip.. the subtitles will be way ahead of the actual voice acting, and then the voice acting will just cut off half way through because according to the subtitles the conversation was over.-There are factions that you can gain repuation with, but having maxed rep or no rep appears to have ZERO effect on anything.-Sometimes there will be multiple ways for you to complete a quest (kill someone or spare them) but again, it doesn't seem to matter or have any effect on the world/quests/other characters. Disappointing.-The game is very difficult at the beginning; you can forget exploring until you are about level 10-15. Unless you want to turn on God Mode.-Story is very confusing if you did not play the first game. I had to look up a summary to figure out who the hell I was and why I was doing what I was doing.Overall, I did enjoy the game (despite a lot of the combat frustration) and I would reccommend it. I got it on sale for $4; I don't really think the original price of $20 is worth it, but if it gets lowered or goes on sale again, definitely give it a try if you are an RPG fan.

												This game is literally awesome.  Great graphics, great open world, great store, great quests - especially the side quests.  I have been thoroughly amazed by the writing and the dialogue. Sooner rather than later since you level so quickly and gain so many skills and stat boosts there isnt much of a challenge.I suggest anyone who likes the Gothic/Risen series give this game a try - its a much more polished, entertaining, coherent game that will last with you long after the game is done.

content:
0, 2014
												This game is literally awesome.  Great graphics, great open world, great store, great quests - especially the side quests.  I have been thoroughly amazed by the writing and the dialogue.  The voice acting is stellar, the main character sounds like Christian Bale's Batman.  A healthy amount of coarse language, not overdone - just appropriate.  I guess my only complaint is that like the Gothic series the combat is leveled for the most part meaning once you plateau past a certain level enemies become a joke to deal with.  Sooner rather than later since you level so quickly and gain so many skills and stat boosts there isnt much of a challenge.I suggest anyone who likes the Gothic/Risen series give this game a try - its a much more polished, entertaining, coherent game that will last with you long after the game is done.

												Really like this game, the graphics and the free motion too. Like the open world and the story line for quests. content:
15, 2015
												I love this game, played it through completely at least twice.  Bought 2 copies, this one for my steam library.  Be aware that many of the negative reviews of this game are based solely upon the (quite legitimate) concerns about intrusive DRM, which we all kinda despise, especially as Steam users we aught not to be subjected to it.  That aside, once the monkey hoops are jumped through, this is an absolutely marvellous game.+ The graphics are amazing and the environments are some of the most beautiful and best of any game I have played, in face I would say THE best.  The savannah is amazing, totally atmospheric, feels like a real savannah aught to, and the Japanese-style college of magick is also gorgeous.  Like something from a dream the designer had and they made it real.  It might be a little dated now, though, that was my impression playing this back few years ago.+ The enemies are not level scaled, which I really like.  Some are very tough and cant be defeated at the start of the game, necessitating going back after your character has levelled a little.  I really like this mechanic, although some folks I know want every enemy to be beatable at any level, like in Bethesda games, which I always usually get bored of as partway through the game your character is more powerful than the game curve and every enemy is toast even on highest difficulty.  So thumbs up to Two Worlds for this, and I hope to see tough, non level-scaled enemies in Two Worlds 3 also.There are lots of other great things in this game but these are the 2 that really stick in my mind.  Horses and boats are great also come to think of it.Anyway this game should be getting 90%+ I think on recommendations, its being brought down by the DRM unfortunatley, but IMHO it's well worth jumping through the hoops to play this amazing game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2015
												Tbh I went into this thinking this game was going to be terrible. Hearing about the 1st was like reading a good horror novel. Many stories all with terrible outcomes and pretty much a constant census....it was a beyond crappy Elder scrolls copy. Naturally with that mass of "don't do it" you would think it's sequel wouldn't be that much better....apparently that was incorrect. Everyone said this was a light year jump compared to the last. Never played the 1st so I wouldn't know but I can say whole heartedly this is a good game. Even though I couldn't verify my code to start the game for a day or so (until I learned Norton was blocking stuff), even though this game lagged at the very start at the dungeon section (updated drivers? idk just started running smoothly after that even though the drivers were for hardline optimization...) and even though for some reason I couldn't skip the start up intro a few times....even with all those headaches this game has turned out amazing. Magic system was confusing as fudge but it's pretty sweet, pretty large world, dialogue is quite funny, quests don't seem too mundane and not a single gameplay issue really (aside for a few slow downs a few mintues ago and a brief freeze.) Overall I think this is a very good game.Best way to sum it up would be to compare it to....Saints Row. Two Worlds 2 is the Saints Row to  Skyrims GTA. Pretty sure I didn't world that properly....but what I mean is Two worlds is like Saints Row while Skyrim is GTA. It's not as refined and polished as it's competition and not fully as serious and more cartoony BUT that doesn't mean it doesn't have it's own fun and uniqueness about it.

The world itself looks pretty good, and it's cool to roam around.The character customization is pretty alright.End of list.Negatives:The controls are really confusing, especially to a beginner. number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2016
												This game was involving, had some nice RPG mechanics (interesting alchemy, smithing and magic), and was overall fun to play.That's not to say it didn't have problems, it had loads of them. But amazingly, all those problems worked towards making the game an enjoyable experience!- It had loads of janky voicing- my characters creepy laughter and the game's habit of cutting off audio dialogue if it was very long (like someone overloading me on exposition) with the next dialogue line gave my character a sort of sleazy funny personality, similar little things with other characters.- It had weird little bugs and glitches that helped with the gameplay (some seriously hard enemies I beat by exploiting this).- Awkwardly half-naked models (that the player awkwardly flirted with) and a story that probably tried to take itself too seriously gave loads of funny moments.So it might not have been a great game in the way the developers would have wanted it to be, but it is definitely recommendable for what it became.

content:
y 15, 2016
												I like the magic system in this game better than the one in Skyrim . You can preset five different spells, and switch between them without stopping the action . You need a staff to use magic, but you can also use the staff defensively to hit your opponents . You make your own spells by organizing what looks like Tarot cards into amulets .... The armor looks better, after you spend some money, but the archer's clothing still looks like something Uncle Joe wouls buy at the local sporting goods store .... There's a bit of humor in the game, and plenty of dungeons .... The inventory system can be confusing at first, because of the (quick switch) system that allows you to change between mage, archer, and fighter instantly .... A spell and a puff of smoke for that (quick switch) would make it more believable .... For some reason, the thieves guild gives you the best prices on any gear .... Don't upgrade weapons and armor too much at first, because the stuff you collect as the game progresses is much much better ....The music is highly atmospheric .... Those stiff hand jesticulations that characters make when talking remind me of cheap old kung fu movies Ha Ha .

content:
29, 2016
												The game is great. I find it rather funny and entertaining, and my only complaint is the framerate.I'm gonna be apologetic about some things that others have criticized:The voice acting: It's not that bad. Certainly better than the majority of anime dubs out there, and really, it's pretty much on par with the voice acting in Skyrim. Which while no huge feat, is still kind of the industry standard.The dialogue:Is it perfect? No. But it is pretty dang funny. The charatcers are full of quips and one-liners with a lot of homages (You're a little short for a City Guard aren't you?) and a LOT of self-mockery, especially directed at the previous game in the series, which are subtle, but you'll catch if you play them back to back.The fighting:It's pretty straight forward attack-button mashing mostly. But when you do come up against particularly tough opponents you can usually find some way to beat them. Otherwise: go level up. It's an RPG. So of course the mobs that are hard at the beginning (Varns: which are Mummy III army of Anubis style jackal-men) become paper thin foes by 6 hours in. The plot:Save the girl. Defeat the evil Emperor. Bad guys from the first game are now the good guys. Pretty standard. Is that bad? I don't think so. It's still an enjoyable story. If you're looking a novel, complex plotline, GO READ A BOOK! It's all plot and no grind! Want suggestions? Message me, I'll give you lists. So unless you're looking to be blown away by some unexpected seldom-before-seen tale of intrigue, wizardry, and shenanigans, it's a good story.As for the sidequest stories. They're ridiculously over the top, asinine, or just straight up obvious comedic relief. One mercenary mission request is a parent and daughter locked in a cellar because there are angry ostriches trying to kill the daughter by touching her with their feathers and causing an allergic reaction. They sent the letter by carrier pidgeon. Is this serious? Clearly not. To those saying the game's stories are stupid: lighten up. Laugh at the game. Laugh at the genre. They're really picking on RPGs as a genre in this game.The mechanics:Plays like a hack'n'slash brawler. I like hack'n'slash brawlers. It can be a bit clunky at times, with your character sometimes crouch to sneak instead of running for his life, but you can fix that by changing the key-bindings I believe.Lastly, the Personal Info requirements:It's your name and address. All public information anyway. All information you've already put into Steam likely more than once. Do you really the Polish game designers care that much about you that they're going to stalk you, or ruin their business by stealing your identity? Or send you snailmail? No. It's for commercial data collection. Statistics. By knowing your address, age, and sex, they can precisely gauge who is buying their stuff and adjust marketing accordingly. That's it.

content:
28, 2016
												After learning about confirmed Two World 3 and upcomming update to engine and new DLC for Two Worlds 2 I decided to play this game again (Need to finally try out rolling a wizard. They have wizard hats, so... yeah...)Lot of people will think this game is not really good. And yes, it's missing a lot. Animations some times can look... weird... Voice acting... Not the worst, some characters voiced just... Boring. Like with the idea of "lets just finish this". It's not terrible just without much of the emotion, makes its sound flat and boring. Character models can look pretty lame too.What's bad too, is that you can't go to multiplayer continent in singleplayer. And by that I mean, in multiplayer there is different island and it's not that small. And while playing singleplayer when opening map you can see that next huge island and you have this "oohhhhh yeahhhh" but later you notice that you just finished game and didn't even played there, turns out - multiplayer only.But the good thing is, theres lots of stuff to do. There's DLC too, that adds new map and stuff. Didn't even started playing that myself (whats bad about it, your character is voiced by different person and it's more annoying than the old one. But when you exploring and collecting stuff he uses lines from the main game "oh, what is this?" and other exploration lines that are voiced by the old voice actor, so it's sounds weird with 2 different voices).......................................................................................................................In the end I wanted to talk about DRM. It is bad and annoying, but Im not sure if most people who review and give negative rating with "Key doesn't work" are stu... Lets just call them... Special... Or what. I reinstalled game lot's of times, re-entered key every time I reisntalled game, just did that today too. Everything works well every time, never had single problem with activation. Key works EVERY TIME. Im not sure what people are doing to mess everything up. JUST REGISTER YOUR KEY TO YOUR EMAIL, IF YOU ENTERING KEY FOR THE FIRST TIME. AFTER THAT, IN CASE YOU ARE ASKED TO ENTER KEY AGAIN, JUST ENTER KEY AND DON'T USE "REGISTER GAME" CHECK-BOX, SO YOU DON'T GET INVALID KEY MESSAGE.

content:
23, 2015
												I'm not going to pretend this game is great, it even borders on bad at times but if youre a big wrpg fan you might let some of the bad things slide and see it for what it does well.Controls are clunky and animations are stiff, but the Gameplay is solid and character progression is good, you have 3 options in how you handle combat, ranged, melee and magic, ranged is probably the worst but i didn't really experience much of it, melee is fairly basic but the skills you can get make it a little better with time, i didn't start to enjoy it until i started parrying(hitting just after blocking) and using my skills more.Magic is insanely good in this game, it works by combining different effect cards with different elements to create your own spells, i'm not sure how many spells there are in the game but a lot of them are pretty unique and creative.The story is pretty average apart from the ending, i don't want to spoil it but the last boss is really dissapointing since you don't even fight him head on.Sidequests on the other hand are great and reminded me of oblivion in some ways, although not nearly as good, you have different guilds that have different storylines that vary in length and then there are a bunch of quests in the world that are both interesting and even pretty funny at times.Graphically it's a mixed bag, aesthetically it's great, the enviroments are varied and pretty unique for a wrpg, you go from an egyptian savannah area to some sort of asian(Korean or Chinese) jungle and finally to a swamp, the assets and environments are good looking but other aspects like animations and character models are pretty bad.One final thing to note is that you have to register an account at the beggining of the game to use the multiplayer, the registration is incredibly intrusive and personal if i remember correctly and i saw that a lot of people marked the game as not reccomended because of it, which i consider completely justified, if you however decide to try the mp(and that's if it's still online)you're going to get a pretty great psuedo mmo tier experience with loads of content and even a village manager later on.

content:
ry 19, 2014
												After 32 hours of gameplay I'm still playing this game and I don't know why. The actual gameplay is fun, but it still has so many problems. I found one game-breaking bug that trapped me in a dungeon, but I was able to get out with console commands. I can no longer stand to hear any of the dialog; the voice acting and script are both so bad.I also sailed to the largest island in the game, only to find out you can't go to it - if you happen to make it in it teleports you back to the shore. It takes a fair bit of time to get there, so don't waste your time trying. You can only go to the small islands on the map.And because I spent some time exploring around before doing missions I'm an unstoppable death machine with no equal in combat - it's starting to make things a bit boring due to the lack of challenge.-------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL REVIEW:I wish I could even play this game. It took a half hour of searching the internet for a way to get the game to even launch and when it did start working, it wasn't due to anything I did because I hadn't changed anything - merely tried to launch it a few more times and then it spontaneously worked (as far as I can tell). Then, once it was running, it kept crashing every few minutes. On top of all of that, they have the balls to put advertisements in the game to try to sell you other things. It also forced all control to my 360 controller I had plugged in without giving me an option to switch to mouse control, which somehow made registration impossible because I couldn't pick a gender."Infuriating" is a rather kind description of my experience with this game so far. I'd like to play it, and I'm going to continue to try for a little while, but after fighting to get it to work at all for this long I simply can't recommend it to anyone.-------------------------------------------------EDIT: Bandicam appears to have been what was causing it to crash. not sure why it wouldn't start up at first. The game is fun, but lips don't match dialog and characters move in cutscenes as if they were marionets. Dialog seems to jump around randomly between subjects sometimes and every now and then it just skips itself mid-sentence as if it expects you were bored.
