												I think this game could be fun but it isn’t that intriguing so its hard to get in to. So if you have anything else to play, you are going to ask yourself why you should play this one. It does not give you a reason early enough. I will out myself that I put in two hours and like 10mins was character creation. The short rating is that the game has stale dialogue, clunky combat, uninteresting characters, and little motivation to push through the tutorial. Cons- The dialogue is cheesy... but not in a fun cheesy way but like in an "I am dark and isolated but not really" sort of way- The controls were not really made for the PC. The controls are clunky and stupid... just saying- The game isn’t optimized well… had random needless unexplained stuttering in empty dungeons. - Needless running in empty hallways in between cinemas. Just play the full cinema instead of having me come in and out for no reason. You literally watch a cinema then walk through an empty room and have another cinema… this is not an exaggeration.- The character creation seemed extremely limited. Basically 10 different choices in each category (plus sliders). So I suppose if you spend a lot of time you can make a very customized character… but I didn’t see any of the features I look for. For example, facial hair options are basically all the same (i.e. short goatee ish beard). Hair options are basically the same length with slightly different styles… very slightly. No facial paint/tattoos. I know I started with I spent 10 minutes on character creation… but honestly it was less than that.- Not sure if this is a fair con or not so I add it only to mention it but the story appears to be heavily dependent on the first game… so a lot is not explained. Pros- Sexy Orc woman who finally helps you understand D&D Half-Orcs- A craft system exist… so that’s good- Variety of combat style (typical though: magic, range, melee). - Interesting lock-picking system- Magic system based on cards. - Not really a pro but another worth mentioned… all the women I encountered so far are scantily dressed women who hold their own… so there is thatI wish I could recommend this game because there seems to be so much potential but that game felt more like a chore than a game… yes first world problems.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
0, 2015
												This game is a combination of good & bad w/ a terrible DRM requirement.NOTE: This isn't really a "positive" review it's just that Steam has no middle ground when it comes to it's user review rating system.  I just think that this game is more recommendable than not so when it comes to what you get for your money.STORY & GRAPHICSThe game revolves around a guy (who I guess was in the first game) who's sister gets kidnapped & he's thrown in jail.  He's later rescued by orcs & has to go around the world to raise an army or something.  Anyways, after all the beginning tutorial stuff you get into it & realize, "Omg... What did I just buy?"  Character models look disturbing w/ huge balogna arms & women have the wierdest & ugliest faces I've ever seen in a video game, especially the witch lady.The graphics overall are something that you have to see.  It definitely feels unique & no other game looks like Two Worlds 2.  The oceans look like jello, the overworld is cartoonish & realistic at the same time.  Everything is unique in an artistic & bad but good way.  The only real displeasing thing about the graphics other than the character models is the terrible motion blur which just adds a fuzz effect to half the screen.  You can turn it off with console commands but you'll have to turn it off every time you launch the game & it does get annoying after a while.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is bad but not unplayable. Melee is the worst since you can't really get hit in this game without getting killed.  Blocking is pretty useless & it's hard to tell if attacks actually connect with what you're trying to hit & you can't really dodge attacks. Magic isn't all that enjoyable but it isn't terrible. It has a unique card crafting system that allows you to customize your magics & you have to equip these cards in order to cast them.  With it you can create a variety of spells.  The downside to this is it's completely useless in the beginning of the game & finding cards needed to make the more powerful spells is a pain.  I spent the majority of my playtime playing as a ranged character which is completely broken due to how poor the AI is in the game & as ranged abilities are extremely OP & easy to use.  If it's your first time playing this game you should probably play an archer.The good part is you can respec anytime you want simply by visiting the witch at the orc encampment so if you want to try something new you're free & able to do it.Also, if you plan on exploring in this game don't do it at low levels.  Don't go into caves, don't go into areas that you're not supposed to.  Just don't do it.  The game's "progression" system just doesn't exist & enemies in caves are most likely much to high in level for you to handle.  It's basically like Morrowind but much worse since the enemy levels are extremely high for being so early on in the game.  You'd be better off using cheats just to get through it.The game's world is probably the best part about the game.  It's huge, open ended & has a lot of stuff in it like wildlife, various towns, ruins, caves & lots of enemies to run into.  The downside is that everything in it wants to kill you.  There is no faction system where you'll see lions trying to eat a monkey or anything.  If it exists outside of a town its sole purpose is probably to kill you.  There are some neutral enemies who won't attack you unless attacked first, at least.There's also a lot of quests to do in this game & some of them have a lot of good humor.  A good early example of one is when I ran into a guy building a house & he said a monkey stole his tools.  Well, I went to find this said monkey & it had nothing on it so I went back to the guy to see what is actually going on.  Apparantly, all the "workers" working on his house were actually armed bandits & he was in the middle of being robbed.  He just made up that story about the monkey hoping you'd think it'd be so stupid of a story you'd notice something was amiss.  Well, too bad for him.  Later when I did the quest again you can see that all the people working on the house are armed & dressed oddly like bandits.  It's a pretty clever way of doing a quest that you don't see a lot of in other games.The game has its charm that's for sure.  There's a lot of humor in the dialog, lots of skills to upgrade & different ways to build your character, there's a good crafting system for equipment & customization. This is a full open world RPG experience & if you're willing to put up with it's flaws there is some fun to be had within the game.OVERALLOverall, the game is good with a side of bad & has issues that just make you not want to play it.  There are some nice moments in the game & there is a lot to do in the open world but the game has DRM which gives you a 3 machine install limit. Any hardware changes to your computer count so if you upgrade your PC more than 3 times you can't download & play it anymore.  You can install it on the same machine unlimited times so if you don't plan on upgrading your rig anytime soon you've got nothing to worry about. You also have to give it personal info such as where you live & meaningless things like your gender.  It's a good game with some flaws but the developers obviously don't care about you even if you buy it so you could very easily pass on the game even if it's on a good sale & I don't blame you if you do.

content:
y 10, 2015
												I have a pretty nice PC but this game is virtually unplayable. it is incredibly jerky and laggy. I generally play with a joystick (instead of mouse/keyboard) and even after adjusting sensitivity it's it doesn't help. I've also adjusted screen resolution and toggled windows mode. Enough about hardware, lets talk gameplay - the story is nonsense, and combat is button mashing and accidents. I generally liked the first Two Worlds game, despite it's many flaws. It seems like these developers were committed to making a sucky game. I can imagine the conversation "Our first game wasn't bad enough - there were still some parts that people enjoyed... So, let's be sure we turn those parts to crap when making our second game!" I've seen other reviews saying the game was rushed and plot holes, etc... This game is bad across the board. For example, ignoring the nonsense story and incredibly jerky gameplay - I can't even figure out how to assign my newly earned skills to one of the 3 Action buttons. I want to replace my fire arrow skill with the newly acquired poison arrow - but there's no indication of how to do this... So, I worked to earn new skills that I apparently can't use. Once more: this game is crap across the board - in evey way. This game has no redeeming value.

content:
0, 2015
												This game is a combination of good & bad w/ a terrible DRM requirement.NOTE: This isn't really a "positive" review it's just that Steam has no middle ground when it comes to it's user review rating system.  I just think that this game is more recommendable than not so when it comes to what you get for your money.STORY & GRAPHICSThe game revolves around a guy (who I guess was in the first game) who's sister gets kidnapped & he's thrown in jail.  He's later rescued by orcs & has to go around the world to raise an army or something.  Anyways, after all the beginning tutorial stuff you get into it & realize, "Omg... What did I just buy?"  Character models look disturbing w/ huge balogna arms & women have the wierdest & ugliest faces I've ever seen in a video game, especially the witch lady.The graphics overall are something that you have to see.  It definitely feels unique & no other game looks like Two Worlds 2.  The oceans look like jello, the overworld is cartoonish & realistic at the same time.  Everything is unique in an artistic & bad but good way.  The only real displeasing thing about the graphics other than the character models is the terrible motion blur which just adds a fuzz effect to half the screen.  You can turn it off with console commands but you'll have to turn it off every time you launch the game & it does get annoying after a while.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is bad but not unplayable. Melee is the worst since you can't really get hit in this game without getting killed.  Blocking is pretty useless & it's hard to tell if attacks actually connect with what you're trying to hit & you can't really dodge attacks. Magic isn't all that enjoyable but it isn't terrible. It has a unique card crafting system that allows you to customize your magics & you have to equip these cards in order to cast them.  With it you can create a variety of spells.  The downside to this is it's completely useless in the beginning of the game & finding cards needed to make the more powerful spells is a pain.  I spent the majority of my playtime playing as a ranged character which is completely broken due to how poor the AI is in the game & as ranged abilities are extremely OP & easy to use.  If it's your first time playing this game you should probably play an archer.The good part is you can respec anytime you want simply by visiting the witch at the orc encampment so if you want to try something new you're free & able to do it.Also, if you plan on exploring in this game don't do it at low levels.  Don't go into caves, don't go into areas that you're not supposed to.  Just don't do it.  The game's "progression" system just doesn't exist & enemies in caves are most likely much to high in level for you to handle.  It's basically like Morrowind but much worse since the enemy levels are extremely high for being so early on in the game.  You'd be better off using cheats just to get through it.The game's world is probably the best part about the game.  It's huge, open ended & has a lot of stuff in it like wildlife, various towns, ruins, caves & lots of enemies to run into.  The downside is that everything in it wants to kill you.  There is no faction system where you'll see lions trying to eat a monkey or anything.  If it exists outside of a town its sole purpose is probably to kill you.  There are some neutral enemies who won't attack you unless attacked first, at least.There's also a lot of quests to do in this game & some of them have a lot of good humor.  A good early example of one is when I ran into a guy building a house & he said a monkey stole his tools.  Well, I went to find this said monkey & it had nothing on it so I went back to the guy to see what is actually going on.  Apparantly, all the "workers" working on his house were actually armed bandits & he was in the middle of being robbed.  He just made up that story about the monkey hoping you'd think it'd be so stupid of a story you'd notice something was amiss.  Well, too bad for him.  Later when I did the quest again you can see that all the people working on the house are armed & dressed oddly like bandits.  It's a pretty clever way of doing a quest that you don't see a lot of in other games.The game has its charm that's for sure.  There's a lot of humor in the dialog, lots of skills to upgrade & different ways to build your character, there's a good crafting system for equipment & customization. This is a full open world RPG experience & if you're willing to put up with it's flaws there is some fun to be had within the game.OVERALLOverall, the game is good with a side of bad & has issues that just make you not want to play it.  There are some nice moments in the game & there is a lot to do in the open world but the game has DRM which gives you a 3 machine install limit. Any hardware changes to your computer count so if you upgrade your PC more than 3 times you can't download & play it anymore.  You can install it on the same machine unlimited times so if you don't plan on upgrading your rig anytime soon you've got nothing to worry about. You also have to give it personal info such as where you live & meaningless things like your gender.  It's a good game with some flaws but the developers obviously don't care about you even if you buy it so you could very easily pass on the game even if it's on a good sale & I don't blame you if you do.

content:
25, 2016
												Two Worlds II gets rid of the best part of Two Worlds - exploration. The original game was a rough RPG, it had many flaws, but it was the exploration that made it a decent game. The sequel is no longer open world, and instead it focuses on storyline, which however, is as bad as in the first game. The NPCs are just as shallow, and the combat remains the same - okay, but nothing special. In consequence, we are left with a game that is average at best, because the excitement of discovering new areas is dimnished by the fact that everything is led by the story, and hence the player cannot go sideways, try to fight much more powerful enemies in hope of much better loot than he is supposed to find. Two Worlds II becomes just an average game with nothing special. I would recommend it only for those who already completed Two Worlds and other good RPGs and have nothing to play. It's okay to kill some time, however, not really worth much. Two Worlds II is a huge disappointment. Instead of improving gameplay in the sequel, developers took away the only thing that made the original game good.

content:
er 27, 2016
												 Two Worlds 2 is a game that is pretty much unfinished. How do I know? The map, the story, the map. I first played the original Two Worlds back in 07. The game was strange to sat the least. The story felt unfinished with entire cities not even used within the story. There was a lack of polish but it did feel like an journey, as well as offered some new things for it's time. Now the 2nd one. Eh...  So at first it seems more polished. The story feels more a part of the game world and not just an after thought. The story is still weak. Your character has to save his sister again, while getting transported to different areas for whatever reason. The story also starts and ends all of the sudden.   Gameplay wise it is a third person hack n slash. Nothing wrong, nothing good either. The boats are nice but needless due to the world mostly being shut off from you openly exploring. Horses are also lame since you only use them on smallish islands.  Sound is ehh. Voice actors try, but their tones don't fit their scenes. Think Oblivion with even less feeling. Graphics are decent for 2011, not on par with Witcher 2 but also no where near as demanding. I play this game at Ultra except AA @2160p 60fps no dips on a 4790k/980ti. The performance is great. Visual options are fairly vast and some advanced setting as well.  The game world is dull and much smaller than the first game. You have a semi large island and two smaller islands. There is a huge hunk of land in the middle of the map but you can not get on it. Atleast not center of it. It is reserved for multiplayer. What a load. You can sail around for hours in a boat, that if you get it stuck on rocks you're stuck. This a mostly empty world.  Atleast they got rid of the old english from the last game. All in all this is a skipable boring RPG. Get Witcher 3, Skyrim, or beer instead.

content:
er 25, 2016
												*Note: I do not *not* reccomend it, but instead I cannot say it's most enjoyable. Due to Steam lacking a neutrual option, despite much ask for it, I mean lean towards this part of the black and white system it has.Review start:The game is, sadly, not as good as the first. It has a good idea for a system, but doesn't do to well. It heavily reminds me of the first Assassins Creed, with the graphics and how running works. Sadly though it doesn't have the good features of it.The combat has changed, and now defensive combat isn't the same, but instead an actual blocking mechanic. The downside is that it doesn't actually block but reduce damage. The magic system and bows have changed for the better, though meele is now worse.When it comes to meele, there is no longer a dodge back mechanic. The block system was instead put in as a replacement, but it fails because like before, it only reduces damage without the overpowered benifits. The idea was good though, and I'd like to see a more realistic version of it in the next game. If it was more so fast-paced realistic combat compared to full on fantasy I think the combat system would be amazing, and work more with the design it has.It still suffers from the RPG sickness most games have, where you are forced to upgrade gear all the time or die. That is annoying for the fact it restricts how much you can customize yourself.Early game it is hard, and unclear why so to many people. Some enemies can be defeated, others cannot with no indication. It doesn't help that your also very weak at the start.One annoying thing that caused me to like the game less is how, right now, to advance in the story I must travel on road, yet the dog people (Forgot the name) are placed right where I must go. It wouldn;t be bad, if i could actually attack them. Not only do their shamans have a cloak that kills me faster then I can attack, but shooting them is useless as they heal faster then you can damage. There is also no limit to their mana for some reason.The inventory is screwed up, or at least the keybindings are now, as it's akward to reach over to F1-7 all the time and memorize it. The old inventory was fine, as items were easy to spot and everything was neat and organized I would say.This is all I have to say for now, and it may change as I play some more, but for now it's a netural leaning towards a sale price. Also if Steam ever adds an actual netural option, as people want, I'll fix the review.

content:
ber 13, 2016
												When this game was released, a friend and I played it but exclusively for the co-op adventure so we could be together. I can't think of a greater injustice. The games Multiplayer \ co-op features are merely a glimpse into what this game has to offer. After years I've thankfully come back to play it, and the single-player RPG is absolutely fantastic. From the markets of Hatmandor, across the archipelago in my own sailboat to the University at Ashos; I love this game. Multiplayer is fun, co-op is great; but single-player is where this game really shines. The graphics hold up tremendously, the music is wonderful, and while some of the voice-acting isn't top-notch; it's light years beyond the first Two Worlds game. I absolutely recommend playing through this campaign. Any RPG fan will adore it.

content:
er 10, 2015
												+ Reworked combat places emphasis on action over animation. Deeper magic system+ Good quest variety+ Music is still great, voice acting is improved+ Lots of minigames that adhere to the experience~ Armor and weapons can no longer be upgraded endlessly~ Alchemy no longer has any negative effects. Once you can make a good channeling potion, you'll forget what dying was like~ Texture quality is improved, but everything else looks awkward. There is way too much bloom and motion blur~ Horse control is improved, but mounted combat is gone. Enemies can now be run over~ Quests now use automatic map markers to show the way. Though it's nice to see where I have to go, I found myself rarely having to actually think to complete quests. It's an imperfect solution that could have been solved through better writing- Game is short and linear. Main quest must now be done in specific order. 4 chapters, and the last 2 can be done in about an hour each. Game tries to cover this up by having a steep difficulty curve. It makes sidequests feel compulsory, as this is where most xp can be found. Boosting your level this way is the only way to make the main quest a fair challenge- Map is much more limited than it looks. Large amounts of land and sea have little of interest and/or are inaccesible. A lot of the time that I've logged on the game has been simply to explore areas that I later found were pointless to explore- Stupid AI. Got a bounty for defending myself in a city. Many enemies can be safespotted- Lots of glitches. That bounty I just mentioned; I got it for fighting back against a character who was supposed to stop asking me for money after a quest. Quest ended, and whenever I got too close to him, I had to choose whether to pay him or fight himOverall, it's sort of "meh". Drops the ball on a lot of the stuff that the first game did fine, while introducing mechanics that feel fresh and more user-friendly. Not sure whether I recommend it, unless you also plan on getting the DLC, in which case it's definitely worth a try.

content:
, 2016
												Holy s**t this is a terrible game.  Lets start off with the beginning.  Why does a game want my name, address, birthdate, and gender?  Blatant refusal to give out all that for a game, so I now live at 69 Nope Rope Avenue.  Secondly is the immersion.  Granted, I had read the reviews before purchasing so I was prepared for a dud, but this is aweful.  You can never go wrong with the cudgel.  You don't even have to hit them and they'll take damage.  When a spell or arrow hits, the sounds and animations are off enough to make you wonder if you actually hit the targets or not.  As for aiming, with magic there's no need.  Just spin around until the purple circle highlights an enemy and fire away, through your body if need be.  Voice acting is meh, but that they tried to animate the lips and bodies to match, but missed the mark entirely is just irritating.  At this point a text dialogue would have been better.Third is the story, or how much I could get through without contemplating burning my PC just for some entertainment.  It's dull and lifeless.  Somebody got kidnapped, and somebody wants you to save them, and you're important but we can't say why, of and I can see the future so trust me.  Might not have been so bad, but the story never ends.  Run from one room to another, and you'll get stopped by some triggered story time.  I barely get to kill two enemies before it's time to listen to someone else ramble on about something that ultimately devolves into fetch and kill quests.So why did I buy this game?  The magic creation system.  I was told it was advanced, and from the gameplay videos it interested me enough to drop $20 (with a coming refund).  Let me tell you know, it sucks.  You first need to unlock skills by finding items, and then you need to find items to craft the skills, and then you need to spend resources to cast the skills.  Maybe if in the first hour you got more than two spells, it could be enough to draw you in, but nope.  Here's a game that lets you craft anything, kind of, with limited variability.So no, don't buy this thing.

												If you like a story with a challenge that you will have to kill every monster and do every quest just to be able to kill things still later then the story part is for you. The online is better than the story in my opinion. This game has one of my favorite spell crafting systems in it ever. You want to make a spell that lets you walk on water, then go ahead. You want a fire ball spell that blinds people and summons 10 skeletons all at the same time, go for it. The spell crafting can be a little overwhelming at first but once you get used to it you can be very op very fast (especially necro tree). There is also a bit of a econ sim with a built in city builder where you make your own little town if you want to. I got this game at full price and have no regrets.

content:
, 2013
												Two Worlds II is a kinda fun rpg whit alot of unused potential.The game is obvious a port and the mechanics are a bit clunky and not as smooth and responsive as it could be. The Story is a bit unrealistic and kinda shallow, Some might even guess how its gona end before geting halfway through the story!When it comes to the Story it's linearly and seems to try cover alot of diffrent cultures (European, Asian and Arabian-African) and most of the time you need to help others with random tedious quest in order to progress. The dialogue in most conversations are boring and uninteresting and even cuts itself off or doesent fit the mouth animation on evry charachter, but the most unsatisfying is the main characters bland voice which more or less kill the mood of evry conversation whit the npc's.One thing where Two Worlds II stands out from most rpg's is the skill tree or development, you are not forced to go down one specific route but have the option to mix magic with stealth and/or other abilitys, for example you could become a two handed water mage (might not be the optimal route but it exist) but sadly the strength lies in the mage class where you can create and customise extremly powerful spells which makes the other classes/abilitys inferior to the mage class/abilitys.one thing alsoe worth noting is that the monster level does not scale well and most of the time the enemys are way to easy or kills you in one hit but the Ai isnt that good which make surviving kinda easy regardless.One thing that realy bothers me is the potential of exploring the game could have had. There are boats you could use to explore the sea but there isnt alot to se in the sea and the boats are not a fast method of travling even the horses arent that great of travling becouse your character has a pretty got pace to his speed and horses can be a bother to find and they cant fast travel with you.in the end the game is still kinda fun its just sad that it have hidden potential and the story that isn't interesting enough. for an rpg i would give it 5,0/10 becouse there are some elements to it that makes the game somewhat diffrent from other rpg's and works well in the rpg genre!

content:
15, 2013
												Two Worlds 2 можно порекомендовать в качестве реабилитационной терапии после недавней Готики. Она на самом деле лучше, прилизаннее, лишена чудовищных багов. Для многих она подействовала действительно как бальзам на душу. К несчастью, при всем старании разработчиков убрать недостатки предыдущей части новые «элементы» резво бьют по рукам, отбивая желание знакомства с этим безумно неудобным шаблонным миром. Спасти ситуацию мог мультиплеер, однако он заведомо обречен на провал. Сервера пустуют. Мультиплеер первой части являлся настоящим пристанищем лагов и читеров, и, несмотря на все заверения, Two Worlds 2 унаследовала все эти черты. Чего стоит только тот факт, что статы игроков хранятся на локальных компьютерах. Несложно представить последствия этой ситуации. Все, что есть в Two Worlds 2 – прилизанное визуальное оформление и отсутствие багов. Последнее на сегодняшний день – настоящая редкость, так что этот факт может являться стимулом для прохождения игры до конца, в том случае если закрыть глаза на неадекватный интерфейс и пустые диалоги. RealityPump «перестарались» – других слов для подведения итога попросту не найти.

content:
er 29, 2013
												As the only person I know who finished the original Two Worlds game (a notroriously awful game which truly was a chore to get through) I was sceptical about playing Two Worlds 2.  I managed to pick it up cheaply as part of a bundle however and decided I had nothing to lose by giving it a go.TW2 is not a perfect game by any means but it is a vast improvement upon the first one.  The graphics are absolutely stunning, the dialogue is much better (althought still a bit cringey), the storyline is much easier to follow and the mechanics have really been cleaned up.  I would say the game's environments are one of it's stongest suit, something which even the first game did particularly well with.  With sprawling savannahs, treacherous tropical rainforests, gorgeous beaches and insidious marshes TW2 has one of the most diverse maps I've ever seen in a game.Other Strong Points- Crafting system (Being able to constantly upgrade your weapon is something I loved about the first game).- Range of weaponry (I really do love a game where I can go from a cutlass to a katana to a halberd to a polearm!)A Few Negatives- Controls can feel a bit awkward, but still much better than the first game!- Dialogue is a bit cringey.- Menus are slightly difficult to navigate, especially the quest log.Don't feel deterred from playing this if you haven't played the original (I played it and I couldn't tell you what the heck it was about) and it is a solid RPG that is definately worth a go.In short; not perfect but better than the first one by far.7/10

content:
22, 2013
												Two Worlds II is a rather enjoyable experience. While it doesn't certainly have the quality BioWare or Bethesda RPGs tend to have, it has some unique features that make it worth looking into, at least.One of these is the combat. The combat in this game is very fluid and diverse. You can choose to play as a warrior, an archer or a mage. There are no preset classes, you gradually become better at your chosen role through leveling up the needed attributes and skills. Sort of like Oblivion in that regard. However you have a set of active combat skills as well, and these vary greatly, from breaking someone's block to countering someone's attack while you're doing the blocking yourself. Even when switching from blunt to slash weapons. Archery is usually done via auto aiming, but the active combat skills that an archer can use will require you to use manual aiming, something which is very welcome. The cream of the crop though, is magic. If you've ever played Magicka, you know how crazy you can get by combining spells to make something truly unique. Two Worlds II? It's the same way. You can customize and build your spells thoroughly, and it never gets old, providing a really rewarding way to play. However, if you're a completionist, and upgrade your equipment well, which is done by destroying unused weapons and armor to gather raw materials to reforge them as upgrades to your current set, (very neat feature) this game will be really easy save for the final battle, thankfully, which is actually challenging.Having at least two different forms of combat is important at any given time for the enemies in this game are plenty and each have their own specific weaknesses. While some will die anyway by just button mashing, it'll take a lot longer if you use the wrong weapon.The plot is.... to say the least, confusing. The pacing is all over the place and I was disappointed with the abrupt and sudden ending, though you can choose to play after the game ends, thankfully, either to tie loose ends or to experience the pirate expansion. (i've not played it so no opinion on it) You do get to understand it fully by the time you're done, but I do wonder if one would have needed to play the first Two Worlds to know everything.The world is quite large and varied with several continents and remote islands with loot ready to explore. You can actually buy a boat and be able to sail it in this game at your own will, something I really got into, except the content for this was sorely lacking. And while I did mention the world is large, which it is, some of it are just smoke and mirrors as 70% of the largest continent isn't even accessible, all you'll get is a "Can't go this way" message and you get teleported out. -_-There are horse races and several faction quests, complete with a gladiatorial arena series of battles. This game took a LOT from Oblivion, but it's different enough to not come off as a ripoff.The graphics in this game are quite pleasing to the eye, and yes, it has a LOT of options to customize it perfectly should you choose to do so. Nothing but thumbs up from me in this regard.The music was okay. Nothing special about it. It did its job but sometimes it could get quite repetitive.The voice acting was not that great. No performances came off as fantastic to me, while some other few cases were completely crap. Your main character loved to sound tough, and he NEVER, NEVER shuts up. Whether he finds or kills an enemy, opens a chest and goes swimming, he'll say one of 5 lines every single time. Get ready to hear him repeat them hundreds of times before the game's finished, which by the way is a bit long, though I seriously expected it to be a lot longer given the game world. If you've went through all the greats in the RPG genre and need a fix for some more, you could do a lot worse than picking up Two Worlds II. While it certainly doesn't feel like a polished game, it's got its heart in the right place.

content:
ry 27
												Well, I'll say I was skeptical when I bought this game as a lot of people were knocking it but honestly I'm enjoying it quite a lot! It is a tad bit buggy fighting in tight places, and somewhat frustrating starting out but once you advance a little and get your stats up it is fun despite what people say. Just don't buy it expecting Skyrim and you won't be dissapointed lol. I'm enjoying the lively soundtrack, the voice acting is over all pretty good and for the most part the landscapes and visuals in general are great for the age of the game. The story line...well it gets you from one quest to the next, it is very much open world so you can wander as you please...however you can easily find youself severely out matched by wandering off the questline too soon. The controller support is a welcome addition as well (and yes keyboard commando types I am aware of your preferances... that works well also) when you have been mouse and keyboard gaming for over 30 years like myself trust me your wrists appriciate the change in position. If you do prefer the keyboard with your young healthy wrists :P then make sure to unplug any gamepads you may have as it defaults to controller without the option to switch if it detects a gamepad. So yeah...I'm running it in Windows 10 Anniversary with a mid range setup and it works flawlessly for me without any tweaking, so far no crashing or glitches. There is a somewhat annoying banner ad for the dlc's on the main page, but nothing of the sort in gameplay. People complain about the registration process...yeah...there is a checkbox to uncheck to skip this... if you just read lol. You do have to activate it...which is different.

												Grandiose Technik, vergleichsweise niedrige Hardwareanforderungen, abwechslungsreiche Szenarien und eine sehr gute Spielbarkeit mit ein paar Designschwächen und Balancingproblemen. content:
ber 28, 2014
												Positives:-Fun and interesting open world with a good story line to say the least. -Extremely unique and original NPC's.-There are a TON of quests to do. I absolutely loved the first two worlds when i played it on the xbox. I literally played my mega high level character that one hit everything so much that the game corrupted, and yes it was buggy and i could go on forever about the bad aspects. -Two worlds 2 to me is a lot more appealing visually and im glad it didnt slack in anything because of it.-overall customization from the first two worlds to the second is still there. -Also the skill tree is identical. (I'd hope to see new skills if another is made)-Is the game is replayable? Very much so. All the time I find a badass staff or legendary crossbow and im on my warrior, or vice versa, and it really makes me want to try to get a similar item that would match my character. you just need to try every hero build and experiment.-Dismantling, Crafting, upgrading, and socketing items is great.-Alchemy is sometimes useful.-Magic system is also very unique and experimental.-I always love third person games but im pretty sure the first could be first person and third, it's been years since i played the first game.And here we go...Negatives:Honestly I'm not trying to polish poop here, the game is well rounded and playable but there's a lot of downsides.-Don't even get my started on horseback riding... -Still the same annoying voice of the character talking to themself, like oh "what's this?" upon finding an item. Characters say "did you miss me" when they run into enemies... ( it rains and he says "just what I needed") sometimes jumping in water they say " ooh atleast it's not cold." and then other times they say the water is cold etc. I love the game but damn it's just dumb hahaha.-I don't really care for the archery in this game its not satisfying to me.-Sometimes it's EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING if quests dont give enough information and you have to run around in an open world for literally an hour sometimes with no direction to try to find what you're looking for by constantly checking your map and equipment hoping for a clue as to where to go.(DLC especially) There's so many islands and often if you don't make good progress you'd never finish the game due to the lack of guidance.-When I play with direct x10 for me it's unplayable there's a lot of bugs.p.s.all right, so there's more negatives obviously like annoying ai's hand gestures repeatedly but thats kinda picky. Ofcourse you're all subject to your own opinion and right now I may be leaving out positives or negatives but i would not pay full price for this game. face the fact that it's not a perfect game but it has original and exciting aspects to it.DO-Watch some youtube clips to see if you'd like it first.-Buy this game if you get a chance to snatch it for 5 bucks or less.-Build epic heroes and experiment with game mechanics.-rate up my review if this was helpful at all. I really do love this game but actually thinking through it and putting down the negatives can only better the cause for future buyers and maybe things like this will be fixed if they ever make another.

content:
28, 2014
												Two Worlds II: Pirates of the Flying Fortress ExpansionJust to reconfirm the following covers my six hours invested in the Two Worlds II (Reality Pump should've been drug out into the street and shot for that title) expansion pack “Pirates of the Flying Fortress” and not the base game itself.I am nowhere near the end of the expansion but after the amount of time invested I felt compelled to race in with good word before this game is lost to Steam's dungeon archives and forgotten all together.Forget what you know about the first game in the series (Two Worlds). Although it wasn't entirely a bad entry in sandbox action/adventure games it mostly certainly left a lot of room for improvement which I feel was successfully implemented in the sequel (or at least its expansion).Now, I must warn to not to do what I did – Which was skip to the expansion immediately without playing the base game first. I warn simply for the fact that your character's achievements and equipment are meant to carry over into the expansion from the base game. If you begin Flying Fortress not carrying over anything from TW2's base; Flying Fortress will start your character with far more than your character needs greatly reducing the challenge that Flying Fortress may have otherwise offered.Not only did I find myself starting off with the best of the best there has been very little acquired during my six hours of play (Armour or Weapons) that improved on what I had. And this game is Loot-Heavy! The looting element in Flying Fortress is on par with the obnoxious pack-ratting found in games like Torchlight so my mistake of starting the expansion first has pretty much killed a lot of the game's excitement during exploration.I feel the best approach continuing onwards is to relay my experience in contrast to The Elder Scrolls games which you more than likely would've asked first and foremost. To summarize: Flying Fortress has sacrificed the massive scope of TES landscapes for a grand improvement of visuals. Reality Pump appears to have aimed for enclosing more relevant and interesting material into a smaller sandbox area. Teamed with very good optimization (modern day developers please look this word up it will help your efforts tremendously!) Flying Fortress plays like a much more aesthetically appealing Skyrim that cuts to the chase.So if I could choose either Two Worlds II or Skyrim? Skyrim simply for the fact of hosting much more content and therefor longevity. Being able to afford both, however, it would be hypocrisy for TES fans to turn their noses up to Reality Pump's entry in sandbox action/adventure genre.Price Recommended: $20 w/ Expansion

												While the combat is clunky to say the least, once you start finding books to unlock more spell types and abilities, the game becomes far more interesting. Combine this with a fairly basic crafting system and you have a decent RPG. I will say this though, there are several bugs that have burrowed their way into this game, whether it is ground polygons having flipped normals causing you to drop into an endless sea, accidentally getting stuck inside of a boulder inside a cave and having to re-load or having enemies getting stuck inside the environment. All and all, 6/10 here. It would get a 7/10 but the dialog is painfully bad at times and it completely takes me out of the experience.

content:
er 9, 2014
												Two worlds (the first game) had a huge map, yet it felt janky in every way a game can feel janky. Two worlds 2, has a tiny map, tiny islands, and for a game with guilds and a supposedly open world, does not have a great deal to discover. So in the end, both games have drawbacks. If you want a huge world, get the first game, just be willing to overlook 1000 different janky elements. If you want a more console, streamlined, slimmed down, rpg time, get this game. It looks better, plays better, and the content while significantly reduced, is of a higher quality level. 7.5/10 for the core game, 7/10 for the expansion which has better writing but a smaller world and a desaturated look that feels a bit washed out and unexiting visually. If you want a skyrim extremely-lite experiance, then you might find that here and have a damn good time.

er 13, 2014
												I do not get how this game is downvoted so much. The so called registration process is just for some silly DLC. just click cancel and you are right in the middle of the main menue.And for the rest of the game: it is what i missed in Skyrim. With Oblivion you can create spells, enchant items and so on... skirim abandoned that feature or simplified it to far. For good or bad is you to decide. But i missed it.Games like Gothic, Witcher, TES are rare enough and TW II is a gem. The Story is good, grafics are nice too. But where this game stands out is the spell creation system. Want anvils to rain down on your opponents and then use the anvils as a shield floating around you? become invisible and heal yourself in combat? That's just fine with the game. Your imagination (and of course some game balancing) is the limit.As i am typing, it is priced below 5 $/€ . So what?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2012
												There is lots to love here for fans of the sandboxy-RPG realm, I suppose. I'm no authority on the genre, but the combat and magic system, for example, actually offers a superior level of fun in some ways than that of titans like Skyrim, IMHO.The musical 'mini-game' deserves a paragraph unto itself. It's Medieval Guitar Hero, with song arrangements that are actually quite inspired and a surprising joy to dabble in with the various bards-at-large in the realm.But at the end of the day, TWII seems kind of hamstrung by flat voice acting, repetitive sound design, and a maddeningly middle-of-the-road stance on how seriously it wants to be taken.At times this tongue-in-cheek, knowing stance works in the game's — and the gamer's — favour, giving it a disarmingly approachable feel for an 'epic' RPG. At other moments, however, you may find yourself desperately wishing it could make up its mind to stop pulling punches and fully embrace one way or the other.

content:
y 2, 2015
												First off, I am unsure why so many people had trouble with the drm? It may possibly come down to connection issues but i only entered my keycode for the game and dlc and continued on. As what you may consider a "veteran" gamer, the whole "register" thing is quite an old system. However the game clearly allows you to skip it and play without registering.Tl;Dr Magic in this game is awesome, if you enjoy games with interesting and fun or even over powerd magic systems (Morrowind i'm looking at you) then you will adore this gem.Anyway onto the review, I mainly will be looking at the Magic system of the game, there are a number of other reviews that can properly describe and highlight the games other excellent aspects. To be honest perfectly honest, prior to reading a few of the positive reviews for the game, I believed it to be a bit of a joke. The graphics from the screenshots looked poor, the combat seemed clunky and generally the whole thing looked a little bit of a mess. However despite these lingering doubts in my mind I persevered. Getting past the tutorial I had already decided to be a mage. (My usual choice due to magic usually being a bit of hax) Magic in Two Worlds 2 is probably one of the things that makes it so great. Generally in TW2 skills are aquired through the acquisition of skill books, don't worry the books are quite plentiful, I havent yet completed the Second chapter and already have unlocked every mage skill and there is always the option of purchasing them from respective guilds/merchants for reasonable sums of money. After you have unlocked the skill you spend points into them to level up, nice and easy. Magic however, differs in that rather than just having spells and combat abilities solely unlocked through skills, it requires you to craft spells using "Spell Cards" these spell cards are received as loot, in chests or as quest rewards. Depending on what skills you have unlocked you can then put the cards together in "Spell Amulets".Spell cards consist of theEffect cards: Fire, Water, Psyche etcCarrier cards: Missile, AOE, Enchant etcModifier cards: Damage, Homing, ProtectionDepending on the level of your skills you can stack cards to increase the power of their effects, as well as the sheer number of combinations. At first you probably will only be able to create a very simple "magic missile" type spell but as you begin to collect a greater number of cards the possibilities start to expand. As an example I will describe a recent scenario that played out during my game. I had a quest to clear out some cultists from a number of houses. My spell reportoire consisted of a Fire spell with two stages, the first spat out three homing fireballs, when the fireballs hit the AOE stage activated, because i had added a "time" modifier onto the spell the AOE fire explosion stopped being straight damage and became a meteor shower lasting about 10 seconds. So each of the three missiles would start a meteor shower ontop of the damage they inflict.The results are quite devestating. However after numerous attempts at destroying the cultists within the house proved fruitless, they seemed to be easily shrugging off the damage. So I switched the spell to use Ice and Lightning damage instead, still the the cultists proved immune to most elemental damage. The beauty of this system is how easy it is to experiment, it merely requires you to swap a card or two in the amulet in order to completely change the spells effect. I eventually defeated the cultists by changing the missile card to an earth card, dealing physical damage and the AOE aspect to a Psyche card, which cause the enemies to turn against each other. It was awesome :)

content:
5, 2014
												Two Worlds 2. Alright so I'm updating this after 2 years because golly it was bad. (This is still going to be bad.)So first off I'm going to base this review on the multiplayer primarily, even though it's not the main focus of the game. Just because of the 70+ hours, 60 or so have been in MP.When you first start MP you are given the choice between varying classes/subclasses. These include a fighter, ranger and mage with subclasses for the fighter and the mage. The subs change various skills and make the player more proficient in different combat styles/magic.Once you enter the your character you can join a European hub server. There are 50 of these each able to hold... 50 players? Not actually sure on that. But once you connect you'll join a small city market district where you'll see other players. From here you can look at shops and meet others. You can then proceed to create a lobby and select a game mode you want to play.As adventure mode is the one I've primarily played I'll be talking about it exclusively.It's a story based coop mode that has small-mid open world maps linked one after each other  based on a narrative. As far as I'm aware you are playing the role of someone serving the main antagonist of the singleplayer. Once you start a game it becomes a listen server and the one who hosted the game is now the host of the server.The combat in the game is... hard to get into, for some. I personally don't mind it, though I wish it did have a back step like the first one. (It might but I'm just blanking on it.) It's a lock-on style combat where one enemy is selected at a time. You are given 3-6 skills on your hotbar to use. In normal stance you can only use three, but holding down right clock changes them to another 2-3.Too lazy to continue.Had more fun in this than Fallout 4, and at least this is a RPG. 8/10

content:
y 22, 2015
												So far, I've only played the so-called Network mode, which I guess it the 'multiplayer' online modes,  and I guess these quests are probably 'ment' for multiple players since the monsters/quests don't seem to scale very good for solo players, and considering I've seen about 3 people playing so far...  Example of this is on the 2nd mission 'through the mine' where countless groups of 5 or so skeletons/Dread Knights spawn from thin air and attack you - its slow going considering the method of running in, killing the ranged mobs and retreating to heal takes along time - its all possible solo until you start running into Tuloks which are practically invinicible not to mention can stun lock you easily, and there are two of them making it nearly impossible single player. Combat is fairly terrible, very minimal defensive options, no dodge and very poor block commands.  For melee characters its more of a spam attacks and hope affair.  At least in the original TW you had a backstep which helped significantly. I haven't played the Single player yet so I'll edit this review to reflect SP mode soon - as for network mode, avoid completely.  If your thinking of buying this game for the MP, do yourself a favor and don't.

content:
r 12, 2012
												This is the game you pick up when playing Skyrim no longer holds your attention. It is a solid sequel to a solid game. It has all the basic RPG elements that it needs to be great, an easily understood levelling system with variety, a well thought out story, plenty of different enemies, an interesting villain, and enough quests to fill the wee hours of the morning as you lose track of time. Two Worlds II has a classless, fluid gameplay that allows you to be what you want to be and couples itself with a combat system that allows for economy of combat without mass confusion. It is interesting and engaging throughout the main storyline while giving you enough digressions to make you feel like a human instead of a mindless automaton set on Cleanse Evil Mode. Apart from combat, great writing and voice acting staple a great experience together and leave you with a thoroughly enjoyable Action RPG that will by no means equal the greats like Skyrim but will fool your clock into thinking it has.

												I remember my first time playing this game. I was awestruck by the graphics and way the weapon system worked. The single player campaign offers a really intresting insight towards a great story that teachs you the basic concept of how attacks work (including how to make your own spells). Later on you may find yourself seeking to play with other players in the multi-player world. I could tell you that in the past, the town was lively with many players seeking lobby games and teaming up with new players. Sadly their are few players left who play in this multiplayer world as they look towards new video games being released. All in all, if your looking for a good campaign game to fight in then I would recommend this one but if your looking for a multiplayer experiance then you might end up being lucky if you find a few players or unlucky if you don't.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												I would give this game a 6/10.The story...very enjoyable and entertaining side quests let you meet some very colorful characters.The Graphics...it is a bit buggy at times, but makes up for that in great scenery and wildlife graphics. I wish they had done as well with the human graphics, they are not horrible but could have been so much better. The water graphics... WOW the best I have seen in a game!The Fighting system...great balance of attack, parry, and defence that makes you think and time your moves for the best outcome. Very enjoyable!The Quest system...very in depth with clues along the way and map marks to help get you where you need to go.The Transportation...boats...horses...teleports...what else does one need? :)The Magic system...fun but complicated. You can create your own spell combinations using 'cards' that you find while exploring, hunting, and buying from merchants. It makes for some fun effects if you have invested in the skill far enough to cast what you have created.The Alchemy system...fun to experiment and make your own recipes that you can save and click a scroll to create later with ease. Water walking potion? Squee!The Crafting system...on the fly and anywhere crafting! Dismantle what you don't need for components and use them to upgrade the stuff you are going to use! And don't forget the dyes...what color do you want to wear? Find dyes at merchants and use them to our hearts delight!Overall I really enjoyed this game...though it is no Gothic, Dragon Age or Skyrim...it was still fun!Mods...I would recommend the Two Worlds Merged, mod. It expands the World into one large map with no barriers, adds more dye options, an in depth add on series of quests that are quite fun and add hours of gameplay...and many other features that add to the fun!

All though the critics gave this title oddly low reviews, its still in my honest opinion a decent game if your just looking to explore ruins and kill rhinos.The other thing I liked about this game is that I was easly able to hdmi my computer to my Samsung LED, hook up my MLG Madcatz usb gamepad and play this game in breath taking 1080p 3D without the need to pay $40 for Nvidia 3d play drivers. The game its self has a built in option to enable top-bottom 3D, or just run it in DX10 if you do not have a 3D capable display.I would say the only disappointment is the quality of the voice overs. Some actors were laking in emotion while others were speaking to quietly.The overall game sound however was done very well, and the implementation of EAX in this game made my 2.1 polk sound setup immerse my living room into a much better sounding atmosphere without the need of a 5.1 setup.(I often found my self loving the 2.1 setup more than my 5.1 logitech I have on my gaming PC)So all in all its not the best free roaming game out there but its still a very good foreign made game, and I look forward to more titles from over seas. In my honest opinion the game industry needs more of this and elss FPS.

Star Wars and Lord of the rings in a mixer - something like that - but i don`t care anyway.For 5€ definately worth a buy.

content:
r 8, 2014
												To be completely honest, i want this to be my first review and i want to give this game a fair as possible review based on what i've seen and experienced so far.Let's start with the obvious- The controls and cameraHmmm, first time ever using spacebar so much, not a good thing but not a bad thing either, just plain weird and hard to do it without really thinking about it.The fact that you've three options of gear, not a bad idea but for god sake don't make R, and T the keys to change gears, R is alright, but T will never be used and is badly placed. H, i never knew it called the horse... Where did it ever say that it called the horse to you? Totally fine with how i'm adjusting the speed  of the horse though.The Camera... Now i don't know about the previous game, but having the camera angel being centered around the character and switching angel with the mouse is not overly different, it has been seen in games like KoAR.  but my god i hate it.Combat.I've so far only been a melee character and i've been wrecked by a lot of creatures... Can't say i like it,  BUT atleast it was a reasonable outcome because most of them ganged up on me. So yeah... nice, but what is not nice, is that the gear i find never really scale with the character, which makes combat darn difficult if i may say so. But the fact that i could do different thing with my character is nice i could change him up a little if the need ever arises. Now i'm getting bored of writingOverall Review on the rest.I'll give it a solid 7/10It has its quirks now and then, i'm in love with how i'm not capable of killing the police with my lvl 19 character. I'm mostly doing sidequest ( Can't even remember what the main quest was about). The inventory is weird as ♥♥♥♥ and i must say that having a high strenght and carry a ♥♥♥♥ load of things is highly weird. Btw i'm in Chapter 1 and have 43.000 gold(btw it was because i lent a lot of my money to this weird guy who wants to set up a shop somewhere in chapter 1) , is that a lot? My horse is stupid, and i've no companions so i feel alone most of the time. My character can be funny, but with the voice acting it kinda puts me off, because the lines and voice doesn't match up that well. I hate that the world is beautiful but the NPCs are thrown into the bad pixel garbagecan.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 19, 2014
												For 5 dollars/ on sale, its worth it. Where as Skyrim has the best dragon ai in any game, Two Worlds 2 has the best magic spell crafting. If you like being a mage and want to make your own custom spell, this is a great game to try. The world environment plays similar to Elder Scrolls Online, mimicing the best it can like Oblivion, while still being a generic mmo on the inside. Its melee warrior combat is dry. The magic side of the game is fun though. Crafting weapons has some depth to it. The creature variety is great. The animations and voice acting is poor. The story is great. (so imagine a great story being told to you with a monotone robot which is hard to listen to). The shear size of the enviroment and its content lies to you. About 50% of the single player map, is unplayable. You start  out thinking the game is !huge!.The side quests have some unique interesting stories to tell, ones you wont forget. Horse riding hits just right. The multiplayer content is short, and enjoyable. You will wish for more. In summary, this game feels unpolished, finding animations not looping smoothly, a few strange bugs, occasional crashing. A few fps spikes. The boss battles are terrible. They.... lack sound effects, tend to have hitboxes that hit you,.. but visually it don't look that way. The creature models look fantastic. How they sound or move is a different story.The game was enjoyable while I played it, and don't regret investing money into it while it was on sale, or still is. It felt shorter than it boasted to be. I was expecting to have more to do after the main quest, seeing the sheer size of the map, which initially excited me. I do recommend the game. Before the ending. I enjoyed my playthrough.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Positives:-Fun and interesting open world with a good story line to say the least. -Extremely unique and original NPC's.-There are a TON of quests to do. I absolutely loved the first two worlds when i played it on the xbox. I literally played my mega high level character that one hit everything so much that the game corrupted, and yes it was buggy and i could go on forever about the bad aspects. -Two worlds 2 to me is a lot more appealing visually and im glad it didnt slack in anything because of it.-overall customization from the first two worlds to the second is still there. -Also the skill tree is identical. (I'd hope to see new skills if another is made)-Is the game is replayable? Very much so. All the time I find a badass staff or legendary crossbow and im on my warrior, or vice versa, and it really makes me want to try to get a similar item that would match my character. you just need to try every hero build and experiment.-Dismantling, Crafting, upgrading, and socketing items is great.-Alchemy is sometimes useful.-Magic system is also very unique and experimental.-I always love third person games but im pretty sure the first could be first person and third, it's been years since i played the first game.And here we go...Negatives:Honestly I'm not trying to polish poop here, the game is well rounded and playable but there's a lot of downsides.-Don't even get my started on horseback riding... -Still the same annoying voice of the character talking to themself, like oh "what's this?" upon finding an item. Characters say "did you miss me" when they run into enemies... ( it rains and he says "just what I needed") sometimes jumping in water they say " ooh atleast it's not cold." and then other times they say the water is cold etc. I love the game but damn it's just dumb hahaha.-I don't really care for the archery in this game its not satisfying to me.-Sometimes it's EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING if quests dont give enough information and you have to run around in an open world for literally an hour sometimes with no direction to try to find what you're looking for by constantly checking your map and equipment hoping for a clue as to where to go.(DLC especially) There's so many islands and often if you don't make good progress you'd never finish the game due to the lack of guidance.-When I play with direct x10 for me it's unplayable there's a lot of bugs.p.s.all right, so there's more negatives obviously like annoying ai's hand gestures repeatedly but thats kinda picky. Ofcourse you're all subject to your own opinion and right now I may be leaving out positives or negatives but i would not pay full price for this game. face the fact that it's not a perfect game but it has original and exciting aspects to it.DO-Watch some youtube clips to see if you'd like it first.-Buy this game if you get a chance to snatch it for 5 bucks or less.-Build epic heroes and experiment with game mechanics.-rate up my review if this was helpful at all. I really do love this game but actually thinking through it and putting down the negatives can only better the cause for future buyers and maybe things like this will be fixed if they ever make another.

												I remember my first time playing this game. I was awestruck by the graphics and way the weapon system worked. The single player campaign offers a really intresting insight towards a great story that teachs you the basic concept of how attacks work (including how to make your own spells). Later on you may find yourself seeking to play with other players in the multi-player world. I could tell you that in the past, the town was lively with many players seeking lobby games and teaming up with new players. Sadly their are few players left who play in this multiplayer world as they look towards new video games being released. All in all, if your looking for a good campaign game to fight in then I would recommend this one but if your looking for a multiplayer experiance then you might end up being lucky if you find a few players or unlucky if you don't.

content:
8, 2014
												If you are one of the many who played the original Two Worlds for as long as you could tolerate it before deciding it was a horrific waste of good code, do not let that experience keep you away from Two Worlds 2.I have been playing RPG's (pnp and pc/console) for a quarter century now and I have to say that I love just about every type of pc rpg, from diablo clones to the Wizardy series, and the Elder Scrolls to Neverwinter Nights.  Like many rpg fans, I played the original Two Worlds, and like many, the game cd for the 360 became a drink coaster, and I have to admit that it is a much better coaster than it was a game.Two Worlds 2 is not that.  While it will only show that I have an hour or two played, I previously owned the game for the 360, and liked it enough that I picked it up on sale here on Steam.  If you set your expectations properly, Two Worlds 2 is a great purchase.  Realize that you are not buying Skyrim.  This is not one of the top ten pc RPG's of all time.  At the same time, it is not Two Worlds either.Two Worlds 2 is an enjoyable RPG experience, with a fair bit of replay value.  There are far worse ways to spend your money at Steam, and at a sale price, this game is a steal looking at it from a hours played/dollars spent ratio.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												I would give this game a 6/10.The story...very enjoyable and entertaining side quests let you meet some very colorful characters.The Graphics...it is a bit buggy at times, but makes up for that in great scenery and wildlife graphics. I wish they had done as well with the human graphics, they are not horrible but could have been so much better. The water graphics... WOW the best I have seen in a game!The Fighting system...great balance of attack, parry, and defence that makes you think and time your moves for the best outcome. Very enjoyable!The Quest system...very in depth with clues along the way and map marks to help get you where you need to go.The Transportation...boats...horses...teleports...what else does one need? :)The Magic system...fun but complicated. You can create your own spell combinations using 'cards' that you find while exploring, hunting, and buying from merchants. It makes for some fun effects if you have invested in the skill far enough to cast what you have created.The Alchemy system...fun to experiment and make your own recipes that you can save and click a scroll to create later with ease. Water walking potion? Squee!The Crafting system...on the fly and anywhere crafting! Dismantle what you don't need for components and use them to upgrade the stuff you are going to use! And don't forget the dyes...what color do you want to wear? Find dyes at merchants and use them to our hearts delight!Overall I really enjoyed this game...though it is no Gothic, Dragon Age or Skyrim...it was still fun!Mods...I would recommend the Two Worlds Merged, mod. It expands the World into one large map with no barriers, adds more dye options, an in depth add on series of quests that are quite fun and add hours of gameplay...and many other features that add to the fun!

I do recommend buying the game together with the DLC in some sale (I got both of them for like two (bucks), play the main campaign if you really have no better games in your sigh or skip it and start with this great DLC (although you will decide to do this you will face a very challanging game if you won't know the gameplay).Oh, and the graphics are meh. Thankfuly the music has some hidden diamonds.

content:
6, 2015
												I have tried to get into this game.  I enjoyed the first one, mainly because I liked the storyline.  Combat was fun, as well.  The only thing that got to me in Two Worlds is the voice acting, which ended up being more comical than deal breaking.I wasn't eager to get Two Worlds II but I ended up getting it during the Christmas Sales not this past Christmas but the Christmas before.  Since then I have given it several tries, as a friend of mine has tried to convince me that it's worth getting through the first part of the game.Pros:1.  Great graphics... I have to give them that.  The scenes are gorgeous and they did a superb job with the modeling (though my guy looked like he was supposed to have gray spots in his hair, but it ended up looking like he had some kind of bugs attached to his scalp).  Armor modeling was awesome.  Their graphics team needs some kudos for their work.2. Uh...  "Better" voice acting?3.  Story line seems interesting.Yucks:The COMBAT!  Ugh!  Way too clunky.  No skill taken into account... it's click as fast as you can with the left mouse button and "hope" you hit them.  The AI is random so sometimes they run away.  You attack a boar and a gang of OSTRICH attack you.  WTF?  Really?  You're surrounded by beasts and you still can't even hit one, even though you're aiming right at it.  And don't even try to use a bow! The physics & targeting system is $#^@ >.<  Sneak attack is overpowered as h.e.double.hockeysticks, if you get lucky and are allowed to use it (seems you can only use it against humanoids) or are even ABLE to use it.  You can't have any weapons drawn to sneak because they mapped block to the same key as sneak, which is also the same key for run.   So you are blocking when you want to run, running when you mean to sneak... you get the picture.Okay... my point... don't get it.  Even if it is on sale.  You'll hate yourself because most likely it's going to be chosing between another game that is on sale.  Go with the other one.  I'm done trying.  Uninstalling forever.  Wish I could just give this dang game away.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 18, 2015
												Full disclosure: I got this in a past Humble Bundle, and thank god I did, because this isn't worth whatever I did pay for it, much less the price they're asking.The graphics aren't bad, and the soundtrack, what I heard of it, is excellent, but who knows what the controls are and whoever designed it doesn't know things like how armor works and how to write an interesting story. The frankly awful DRM, which, while I understand their desire for demographic research and the ability to mail/email me promotions, I own this on Steam I've hardly stolen it, is just the cherry on top I'm afraid. I'm frankly not going to enter my CD key every time I play, especially not if I have to give some unknown thing a bunch of my personal information, including my physical address just to get the game I own out of demo mode. It's buggy and difficult to play (I got trapped halfway inside a gate three cutscenes in) and just, not that much fun.I really, really wanted to like it. The cutscene martial arts look like something straight out of a Chinese Period drama, all slo mo and flying through the air and fancy tricks, on paper it has an interesting premise, but it needs some serious TLC before it'll be worth playing.

content:
, 2015
												Again I wish there was a middle option between recommend and not.Two Worlds 2 is a great improvement over the first game which was a complete crap hole. Its really "janky" kind of like deadly premonition. Iits got a bad but loveable feel to it. The dialouge is entertaining and some characters are well enough written. The combat system isnt amazing but it works. Actually, thats a pretty good summary about everything in this game. Its not amazing but it works.It wears out its welcome though. So many side quests and fetch quests and the main story quests never really go anywhere. I forgot what I was even doing half the time.I played about 18 hours of the game and didnt quit out of hate or rage. I quit out of.... disdain? I just didnt really care to keep going.If you are really in to open world action rpgs, and can get past some janky controls, then get the game on a sale. Otherwise you can pass this one up.

content:
, 2015
												A lot of people on steam will play a game for 10 minutes and judge the entire thing based on that. the first time i played this game my save deleted itself 6 times. 3 months later i tried it again on a slow sunday and when i realised my save was fine the next day i kept playing... and kept playing... and kept playing until my macbook overheated on the train. it's not the best game out there not by a long hot but if you have the time and the patience you wont be displeased. its combat can get boring at time but you can change your style so much in one playthough that it really doesnt matter i mean for example The Witcher was one of my favourite games when it was first released but the combat in that game had me in tears. There arent many games that will let you beat a Rhino to death with a sledge hammer or have monkey's throw ♥♥♥♥ at you while riding your horse (the horse is also broken). The game has this Instagram like filter over it when you're out in the open and it kills your eyes after a while but sometimes... just sometimes you'll lookat your scrren after you've fought your way through an entire field of warthogs and think... this doesnt look like ♥♥♥♥ on a stick.It's a game I'd advise anyone to play. I had fun playing it and these reveiws arent all about if a game is broken or has bugs or not because there isn't a game out there that has NO bugs what so ever. So give it a try... maybe buy it on a sale though... £14 is a little steap for a game that has made my punch my standing fan.

												This game is really poor. It looks quite good, although the combat system is actually full of odd glitches (weird jumping, drowning horses, poor interaction with the terrain). The main problem is that the plot and quests are insanely stupid. They make no sense in driving the story forwards (just putting hurdles put in a player's way and making them jump over them) and generally make almost no sense even in the game's terms (like a riding race you need to win, which is witnessed by no-one and in the end the current holder of the title just accepts whatever you say - "yeah, sure I did it faster than you!"; except you're not allowed to say this until you do "win" the race).I lost interest after about 10-15 hours and I won't go back to it.

content:

												Although I usually try to give games several hours to draw me in, I find myself completely unable to do so with this one.  While the game doesn't look terribly bad, the animations and combat are abysmal at best.  The voice acting is decent but the conversations involve people going through one of two really low quality animations that just look like everyone is shrugging.  The default key bindings are incredibly odd and while they are rebindable, the way the combat works makes it redundant.  Going into stealth mode requires you to be standing completely still, as does blocking.  If you are moving at all you will instead start sprinting.  Targetting is hit and miss and I simply did not want to continue playing after the short time I had with the game.
